The proposed activities were assessed as fully in line with Sida's request and the decision was made 30 June 2020 to add SEK 42m, to extend the activity period with 12 months until 31st August 2021 and the validity of the agreement until 31 December 2022. Through the decision UNICEF were given the flexibility to go beyond the original programme's geographic focus on the West Nile region in order to be fully needs based. This is reflected in the inclusion of only non West Nile districts for the pandemic response activities (outcome 1) and the inclusion of the Kawempe referral hospital for support to continuity of essential services under outcome 2, which otherwise only focuses on West Nile. Kawempe Hospital serves as the national referral hospital focusing on maternal, newborn and child health conditions and delivers 80-120 mothers daily of which approximately 30 % require c-section and over 10% require critical care. The support to Kawempe is motivated by Kampala having the highest numbers of maternal deaths between July 2019 and April 2020, with an institutional maternal mortality ratio at 145.8 against a national average of 93.5 per 100,000 deliveries. Approximately 71% of these deaths were registered in Kawempe Hospital. Furthermore, the monthly average for maternal deaths has increased in the context of Covid-19 with more than half of the deaths happening between January and April 2020. Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Stöd till demokratiska institutioner som lyder under parlamentet i syfte att stärka dess möjligheter att genomföra sitt mandat på ett mer oberoende sätt.

Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 Support to the main accountability mechanism in Ethiopia in order to contribute to that they can implement their core mandate in a more independent and professional manner.

tag.narrative: 10.3 - Ensure equal opportunity and reduce inequalities of outcome, including by eliminating discriminatory laws, policies and practices and promoting appropriate legislation, policies and action in this regard.

10.3 - Säkerställa lika möjligheter och minska förekomsten av ojämlika utfall, bland annat genom att avskaffa diskriminerande lagstiftning, politik och praxis och främja lagstiftning, politik och åtgärder av lämpligt slag i detta hänseende.
16.10 - 0 Säkerställa allmän tillgång till information och skydda grundläggande friheter, i enlighet med nationell lagstiftning och internationella avtal.
16.10 - Ensure public access to information and protect fundamental freedoms, in accordance with national legislation and international agreements.
16.3 - Främja rättssäkerheten på nationell och internationell nivå samt säkerställa lika tillgång till rättvisa för alla.
16.3 - Promote the rule of law at the national and international levels and ensure equal access to justice for all.
16.5 - Substantially reduce corruption and bribery in all their forms.
16.5 - Väsentligt minska alla former av korruption och mutor.
16.6 - Bygga upp effektiva och transparenta institutioner med ansvarsutkrävande på alla nivåer.
16.6 - Develop effective, accountable and transparent institutions at all levels.
16.7 - Ensure responsive, inclusive, participatory and representative decision-making at all levels.
16.7 - Säkerställa ett lyhört, inkluderande, deltagandebaserat och representativt beslutsfattande på alla nivåer.
16.b - Promote and enforce non-discriminatory laws and policies for sustainable development.
16.b - Verka för och genomdriva icke-diskriminerande lagstiftning och politik för en hållbar utveckling.
5.1 - Avskaffa alla former av diskriminering av alla kvinnor och flickor överallt
5.1 - End all forms of discrimination against all women and girls everywhere.
5.2 - Avskaffa alla former av våld mot alla kvinnor och flickor i det offentliga och privata rummet, inklusive människohandel, sexuellt utnyttjande och andra typer av exploatering.
5.2 - Eliminate all forms of violence against all women and girls in the public and private spheres, including trafficking and sexual and other types of exploitation.
5.5 - Ensure women’s full and effective participation and equal opportunities for leadership at all levels of decision-making in political, economic and public life.
5.5 - Tillförsäkra kvinnor fullt och faktiskt deltagande och lika möjligheter till ledarskap på alla beslutsnivåer i det politiska, ekonomiska och offentliga livet.

description.narrative: Some important results of this programme are as follows: - The house of people's representative created a platform interaction with the legislative branch at regional and federal level to deepen the understanding of separation of powers and the role of parliament in a democratisation process. Internally the HoPR strenghten its capacity on digitalisation and documentation. The periode has witness great improvements in terms of accessiblity and transparency of the work of the HoPR. - The Ethiopian Ombudsman has increased its capacity in case management. - The AG has compiled all active domestic laws into one document making them easy available to legislative staff. - Several institutuions like FEACC, EIO and OFAG have worked on making their systems conducive for accountablity, transparency and responsiveness, for example a public platform for anti-corruption agencies has been created. This platform also includes non-state actors. This has enable the country to address corruption in a more systematic manner. - Public awareness on ethics, integrity and anti-corruption has also increased after the production and broadcasting of a number of radio and tv-programmes on the topics. - A series of dialogues have been conducted in order to open the space for dialogue among state and non-state actors. This has led to an improved relationship between civil society and government authorities. One outcome of this was the new CSO legislation in 2018 that opened up civil space and allows for CSO advocacy, including on human rights.. - Capacities of NEBE, the institution with the main mandate to organised and supervise the upcoming national elections, have been strengthened. - The programme has further been instrumental in kick-starting the ongoing media reform. A draft media policy has been developed and a draft assessment of the media landscape has been developed and formed important inputs to the media reform. A new media law will soon be decided, expected to strenghten media independence and freedom of expression, among other things. - The implementation period has seen a lot of civil unrest and the programme has focused on contributing to inclusivity, social cohesion and a culture of peace, unity and tolerance. For that purpuse the programme has worked closely with actors like Inter Religious Council of Ethiopia and the former Ministry of Federal and Pastoralist Affairs. The programme has organised a number of conferences to facilitate dialogue among community representatives, religious leaders, women and youth groups. -On the overall, the GDPP partners have acheived som very important results over the last year, contributing to more accountability, transparency and participation in activities of institutions key to democracy. -During last year there was special focus on inclusive political processes, including improvements in the parliament’s oversight mechanisms, and enhanced opportunities for the public to access information and participate in development processes. -As a result of this programme, engagement with civil society is increasing. -There has also been important progress in developing the peace architecture and conflict prevention systems and mechanisms. -Gender equality being fundamental to democratization, all institutional partners of the programme have now conducted gender analyses and have plans for mainstreaming. -The promotion and protection of human rights have also had progress in the programme, with the institutionalisation of legal services to marginalized people, the establishment of 4 human rights centra, and with special focus on women’s access to human rights. -The monitoring and reporting on human rights has also increased due to this intervention, and it is important to keep up the good work in this regard.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

Omprogrammerade medel för att bekämpa covid-19 Insatsen bygger på tidigare svenskt stöd till media-reformer i Etiopien. Kopplat till aktuella, pågående demokratiska reformer i Etiopien syftar projektet till att ta tillvara möjligheterna att skapa förhållanden för att uppnå följande resultat:
- Nyckelaktörer stärks i arbetet med att utveckla ett juridiskt och institutionellt ramverk som stödjer en fri och oberoende media, garanterar tillgången till information och underlättar för informerade och engagerade medborgare; - Målgrupper inom media får stärkt finansiell hållbarhet och publicerar media av allmänt intresse, inklusive bland kvinnor, män, olika åldersgrupper samt olika befolkningsgrupper.

Reprogrammed funds to address COVID-19 This contribution builds upon previous Swedish support to media reforms in Ethiopia. Seizing opportunities created by the current on-going democratic reforms in Ethiopia, the project aims to contribute to the following objectives:
- Key actors are strengthened to contribute to developing and implementing a legislative and institutional framework that supports a free and self-regulating media, ensures public access to information and promotes an informed and engaged citizenry; - Targeted media are strengthened to become financially sustainable and to produce and disseminate public interest journalism, reflecting the full composition of society through a balanced presence of women and men, age groups and communities.

The programmes overall objective is to insure that "men and women in Ethiopia have access to independent and balanced interest journalism, enabling democratic and peaceful citizen engagement and accountable governance" Two specific objectives are "key actors contribute to an overall media reform in Ethiopia to ensure an open, diverse and democratic media landscape, and to the production and dissemination of public interest journalism characterized by professionalism, gender equality and inclusive community engagement" and "Women, men and youth living in marginalized communities, including refugees, IDPs and hosts, to exercise their agency to initiate and participate in inclusive public dialogue and discussions" In line with this, two main outcomes have been defined: Outcome 1: Key actors are strengthened to contribute to developing and implementing a legislative and institutional framework that supports a free and self-regulated media, ensures public access to information and promotes an informed and engaged citizenry. Outcome 2: Targeted media are strengthened to become financially sustainable and to produce and disseminate public interest journalism, reflecting the full composition of society through a balanced presence of women and men, age groups and communities.

title.narrative: COVID-19 Oxfam DRC Governance and community protection Program -Our rights and our duties
COVID-19 Oxfam DRC Governance and community protection Program -Our rights and our duties

description.narrative: In its essence, the program aims to create new and transform existing relationships to bring about a shift in the power relations that currently keep women subordinate to men, youth and minorities excluded from opportunities, and citizens subject to the will of authorities. Once created or changed, new relationships will be nurtured, strengthened and sustained to the extent that they are deemed valuable by those who are party to them. Oxfam proposes a program to advance the goal of a DRC in which women and men, civil society organizations, and community groups are able to exercise their rights, secure protection from violence and abuse, voice priorities, and participate in decisions that affect their lives. To achieve this, in this program Oxfam will be working in two provinces in East (South Kivu and Tanganyika) and one in the West (Equateur) of the DRC. The program will: - Enable communities, local public institutions and CSOs to adopt new or change current practices and attitudes to increase respect for human rights and women’s rights, and reduce discrimination and violence; - Support community-level governance committees, including women’s forums, to build the capacity and confidence for collective action that engages territorial and provincial authorities to improve the accountability of governance, respect for gender equality and effectiveness of protection processes; - Establish and facilitate a citizen-state consultation process by which authorities at provincial, territorial and local levels adopt practices and procedures in response to citizens’ demands for increased accountability, transparency, inclusiveness of governance, increased respect for gender equality and increased protection of citizens’ rights; - Strengthen the capacity of national advocacy organizations to apply an evidence-based approach that represents the views and incorporates the testimonies drawn directly from local civil society organizations and ordinary citizens, to be more effective and credible in their advocacy efforts. To demonstrate the possibility and test a model of effective bottom-up change in DRC, Oxfam will build on programs proven effective in bringing about lasting individual and local level change, to address the more systemic governance, protection and equality issues that can only be achieved with engagement by higher levels of government. The program’s direct beneficiaries will be the individuals trained to serve as change agents; as well as the community governance structure, women’s forum members, local, territorial and provincial formal and traditional authorities who participate in program trainings and other activities. Direct beneficiaries (examples) 720 Change agents trained in 24 locations, 50% men, 50% women, 30% of the total youth Each change agent will reach out to at least 15 people in the project cycle – which leads to 10 800 change agents. Change agents will reach out at least to 2 public institutions at the community level: 48 public institutions and interaction with several individuals from each institution Indirect beneficiaries: 72,000 community members in rural areas, based on communities of 3,000 inhabitants 500,000 through communication activities (including reach on social networks) Indirect beneficiaries at territorial, provincial and national level will be assessed during start-up phase

Omprogrammerade medel för att bekämpa covid-19 Oxfam har ansökt om finansiering på 52 901 215 SEK från Sida för att genomföra programmet “Governance and Community Protection Program 2018-2022 - our rights our duties in DRC” under perioden 2018 till 2022.
Programmet förväntas bidra till att kvinnor och män, civilsamhällsorganisationer och andra samhällsgrupper bättre: * kan utöva sina rättigheter * kan få ökat skydd mot våld och övergrepp * stärker sina röster och bättre kan delta i beslut som påverkar deras liv
Programmet omfattar: *Stöd till lokala offentliga institutioner och civilsamhällsorganisationer för vägledning till att införa nya, eller förändra rådande policys och attityder för ökad respekt för mänskliga rättigheter och kvinnors rättigheter samt för att minska diskriminering och våld.
* Stöd till kommittéer på lokal nivå, inklusive kvinnoforum, så att de kan stärka sin kapacitet och öka sitt förtroende för kollektiva åtgärder. Detta för att de ska kunna ställa högre krav på lokala och provinsiella myndigheter kring förbättrad förvaltning, respekt för jämställdhet och effektivitet i skyddsprocesser.
* Arbeta för att myndigheter på provinsiell och lokal nivå antar och förstärker praxis och processer i enlighet med medborgarnas krav. Dessa krav ska förverkligas genom regionala samrådsprocesser på medborgarnivå. Arbetet kommer att präglas av ökat ansvarsutkrävande, transparens, inkludering, ökad respekt för jämställdhet samt skydd av medborgerliga rättigheter.
• Stärka nationella organisationers förmåga att på ett bevisbaserat sätt som representera medborgarnas åsikter och införliva de vittnesmål som kommer från lokala civila samhällsorganisationer. Detta för att de ska vara mer effektiva och trovärdiga i sin plädering för förändring.
Oxfam kommer att genomföra insatsen tillsammans med lokala organisationer i tre provinser: Equateur, Syd-Kivu och Tanganyika. Insatsens totala budget uppgår till 52 901 215 SEK och Sida är den enda givaren till programmet.

tag.narrative: 16.6 - Bygga upp effektiva och transparenta institutioner med ansvarsutkrävande på alla nivåer.
16.6 - Develop effective, accountable and transparent institutions at all levels.

title.narrative: Oxfam DRC Governance and Community Protection Program - Our Rights and our Duties, Grant Agreement
Oxfam DRC Governance and Community Protection Program - Concept Note

description.narrative: Concerning the progress, the program focused its interventions and achievements in two provinces (Equateur and South Kivu) and on outcomes 1, 2 and 3 as indicated in the program proposal. The results achieved in these two provinces have shown that the activities were mainly focused on the change agents, members of the community governance structures and Women's Forums and that, these members and change agents, with the support of the local authorities, are engaged in the fight against discrimination, violence and human rights violations. The first activities related to the set up of the structures (change agents, community governance structures and women forums) and the capacity-building of the members of these structures were implemented and members embarked on initiatives to boost change in others in practices and attitudes. In addition, the results of the program demonstrated a weak involvement of the territorial and provincial authorities, although at the local level, the local authorities (Heads of village, sub-village, heads of group, sub-commission of Police) remain very involved in the implementation of the activities. This is justified by a lack of activities carried out with these authorities. Indeed, the members of the Community Governance Structures have weakly engaged the provincial and territorial authorities during this first phase and still have difficulties with the advoccay’s techniques, which the program will try to fill in during the second year of implementation in order to build and strengthen the capacities of the structures in leading actions to resolve identified problems in their communities on one hand and to better collaborate with the provincial and territorial authorities on the other. South Kivu's contextual analysis conducted by Oxfam in July 2019 as part of the program, found that women, girls and boys and other groups (Albinos and Pygmies) are often discriminated and are not involved in the decisions that affect their lives. Their opinions are neither followed nor listened to. This situation is justified by the retrogressive customs thus disadvantaging the woman, by the ignorance of the rights and laws and by the mistrust between the citizens and the authorities. Despite all challenges, these activities were organised : - 8 meetings were held in the target villages to present the program to community members in South Kivu Province. A total of 753 people took part in the sessions including 386 men and 367 women. - 240 change agents and 120 members of the women's forums elected through this activity. Among these members are 11 representatives (AC) of Indigenous Peoples (4 women and 7 men) and 5 representatives (FF) of indigenous peoples. - 56 training sessions including 32 training sessions in South Kivu (4 sessions per village) and 24 sessions in Equateur (3 sessions per village) were organized during this first year for Change Agents in target areas of the program. These sessions focused on the Modules 1 and 2: human rights, constitutional rights, power, equality, women's participation, the inclusion of other marginalized groups. - 480 people were reached by these sessions including 240 women and 240 men. These individuals, trained and helped to act as agents of change, set up action plans for their activities in South Kivu and Equateur based on human rights issues, violence against women, discrimination according to the problems of each village and disseminate information door-to-door on the care services available in the areas to facilitate self-referencing cases. - 339 people took part in these sessions including 219 people in South Kivu of which 117 were men and 102 were women and 120 people in Equateur of which 144 were women and 56 were men. Barriers identified during this activity have been more oriented towards the negative attitudes, practices and behaviors of the service providers available in each community that do not promote easy access and fair treatment of members of the community. As an example, as barriers identified at the health services: Poor processes in the medical prescription.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Asia Disaster Preparedness Center, ADPC, har av Sida ansökt om ca 5 933 0000 USD (54 miljoner kronor) för att genomföra "Building resilience through inclusive and climate-adaptive disaster risk reduction in Asia-Pacific 2017-2021” i Asien och Stillahavsområdet under perioden 2017-2021.
ADPC är en icke-vinstdrivande regional organisation som grundades 1999 och arbetar för säkrare samhällen och en hållbar utveckling genom katastrofminskning i Asien och Stillahavsområdet. ADPC: s genomför genom projekt och program utbildning, information- och kunskapshantering samt annat tekniskt stöd avseende katastrofriskreduktion. ADPC samarbetar med lokala, nationella och regionala regeringar, statliga och icke-statliga organisationer, givare och utvecklingspartners för att uppnå sina mål inom katastrofriskreducering. ADPC’s regionala kontor ligger i Bangkok och man har landkontor i Bangladesh, Myanmar och Sri Lanka. ADPC är sedan år 2000 sekretariat för Regional Consultative Committee on disaster management (RCC) vilket består av National Disaster Management Organisations (NDMO’s) från 26 länder* i Asien och Stillahavsområdet. RCC är ett unikt forum som fokuserar på genomförandet av katastrof- och klimatriskhanteringsinitiativ samt samarbetar kring genomförandet av de globala och regionala ramverken inom utvecklingsagendan på nationell och regional nivå.
Det femåriga programmet syftar till att förbättra den regionala kapaciteten för samarbete gällande katastrof- och klimatriskhantering med det övergripande målet att bygga motståndskraft och anpassningsförmåga hos människor i Asien och Stillahavsområdet. Programmet arbetar med nationella myndigheter, civilsamhälls-organisationer och regionala organisationer genom Regional Consultative Committee on Disaster Management’s (RCC’s) vars medlemmar är katastrofhanteringsmyndigheter i 26 Asiatiska länder. Programmets huvudfokusområden är: katastrofberedskap och hantering av humanitär respons; ökad användning av riskinformation och data uppdelat efter gender, ålder och handikapp; integrering av katastrof- och klimatfrågor i nationella och regionala utvecklingsprogram och i policy; ökad användning av inkluderande tillvägagångssätt inom riskreducering och katastrofberedskap; främjande av jämställdhet och kvinnligt ledarskap inom riskhantering, samt stärkande av Regional Consultative Committee on Disaster Management’s (RCC’s) och dess regionala roll som stöd till medlemsländerna i genomförandet av globala överenskommelser och facilitator för syd-syd-lärande, gränsöverskridande riskreducering och kunskapsdelning. Direkt målgrupp för programmet är framförallt nationella katastrofmyndigheter genom RCC. Slutlig målgrupp är kvinnor och andra särskilt utsatta grupper. Förslaget nämner inte ursprungsbefolkningar per se men fokuserar på mest riskutsatta grupper. ADPC kommer att genomföra programmet tillsammans med Myndigheten för Samhällsskydd och Bevarande (MSB), Stockholm Environment Institute (SEI-Asia) och Raul Wallenberg-institutet (RWI).
*Afghanistan, Bangladesh, Bhutan, Brunei, Cambodia, China, Georgia, India, Indonesia, Iran, Jordan, Kazakhstan, Lao PDR, Malaysia, Maldives, Mongolia, Myanmar, Nepal, Pakistan, Papua New Guinea, Philippines, South Korea, Sri Lanka, Thailand, Timor Leste, Vietnam

Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 Asia Disaster Preparedness Center, ADPC, has applied to Sida for funding of 5 933 000 USD (54 million SEK) to carry out the "Building resilience through inclusive and climate-adaptive disaster risk reduction in Asia-Pacific" in Asia and Pacific during the period 2017-2022.
The five-year program aims to enhance regional capacity for cooperation on disaster and climate risk management with an overall objective of building resilience of people in the Asia-Pacific region. This will be achieved by building on current good practices and providing technical assistance to select governments, civil society organizations and regional bodies. Key focus areas of the program include: emergency preparedness and humanitarian response management; facilitating the use of risk information and sex-age-disability-disaggregated data by policy makers and disaster managers; integrating disaster and climate change concerns into development policy and programs; promoting inclusion and protection-sensitive approaches in risk reduction and disaster preparedness, promoting gender equality and women leadership for risk resilience; and enhancing the role of the Regional Consultative Committee on Disaster Management (RCC) to support member countries on implementing global frameworks and serving as a conduit for South-South learning, transboundary risk reduction and knowledge sharing. ADPC will implement the intervention together with the Swedish Contingency Agency, MSB, Stockholm Environment Institute –Asia, and the Raul Wallenberg Institute.

tag.narrative: 1.5 - By 2030, build the resilience of the poor and those in vulnerable situations and reduce their exposure and vulnerability to climate-related extreme events and other economic, social and environmental shocks and disasters.

1.5 - Till 2030 bygga upp motståndskraften hos de fattiga och människor i utsatta situationer och minska deras utsatthet och sårbarhet för extrema klimatrelaterade händelser och andra ekonomiska, sociala och miljömässiga chocker och katastrofer.

11.5 - By 2030, significantly reduce the number of deaths and the number of people affected and substantially decrease the direct economic losses relative to global gross domestic product caused by disasters, including water-related disasters, with a focus on protecting the poor and people in vulnerable situations.

11.5 - Till 2030 väsentligt minska antalet dödsfall och antalet människor som drabbas av katastrofer, inklusive vattenrelaterade katastrofer. Även tillse att de direkta ekonomiska förlusterna till följd av sådana katastrofer, i form av lägre global BNP, minskar väsentligt. Särskilt fokus bör ligga på att skydda de fattiga och människor i utsatta situationer.

11.b - By 2020, substantially increase the number of cities and human settlements adopting and implementing integrated policies and plans towards inclusion, resource efficiency, mitigation and adaptation to climate change, resilience to disasters, and develop and implement, in line with the Sendai Framework for Disaster Risk Reduction 2015–2030, holistic disaster risk management at all levels.

11.b - Till 2020 väsentligen öka det antal städer och samhällen som antar och genomför integrerade strategier och planer för inkludering, resurseffektivitet, begränsning av och anpassning till klimatförändringarna och motståndskraft mot katastrofer samt utveckla och genomföra, i linje med Sendai-ramverket för katastrofriskreducering 2015–2030, en samlad katastrofriskhantering på alla nivåer.
13.1 - Strengthen resilience and adaptive capacity to climate-related hazards and natural disasters in all countries.
13.1 - Stärka motståndskraften mot och förmågan till anpassning till klimatrelaterade faror och naturkatastrofer i alla länder.
13.2 - Integrate climate change measures into national policies, strategies and planning.
13.2 - Integrera klimatåtgärder i politik, strategier och planering på nationell nivå.

13.3 - Förbättra utbildningen, medvetenheten och den mänskliga och institutionella kapaciteten vad gäller begränsning av klimatförändringarna, klimatanpassning, begränsning av klimatförändringarnas konsekvenser samt tidig varning.
13.3 - Improve education, awareness-raising and human and institutional capacity on climate change mitigation, adaptation, impact reduction and early warning.
5.1 - Avskaffa alla former av diskriminering av alla kvinnor och flickor överallt
5.1 - End all forms of discrimination against all women and girls everywhere.
5.5 - Ensure women’s full and effective participation and equal opportunities for leadership at all levels of decision-making in political, economic and public life.
5.5 - Tillförsäkra kvinnor fullt och faktiskt deltagande och lika möjligheter till ledarskap på alla beslutsnivåer i det politiska, ekonomiska och offentliga livet.

description.narrative: This summary covers the period July 2019 - December 2020. A sample of results from the BRDR program during the period include: - The Philippine Institute of Volcanology and Seismology has, through the BRDR programme, begun engaging with the Commission on Human Rights and the Philippines Commission on Women to integrate rights based approaches and gender equality into disaster risk reduction activities. - A Regional Technical Working Group on Inclusive Approaches to Localization (TWG-IAL) has been established under the Asia Preparedeness Partnership (APP) that is active in Bangladesh, Cambodia, Myanmar, Pakistan, Philippines and Sri Lanka. Both BRDR and APP are committed to exploring how human rights and gender equal approachens can enhance prparedeness for responses at local levels. The establishment of the TWG-IAL is an example of how the BRDR programme is influencing other DRR programmes in the region. - The 15th Regional Consultative Committee on Disaster Management (RCC) took place during January 2020. "Enhancing Regional Cooperation and Coherence for Resilient and Inclusive Societies" was the theme of this 15th RCC that took place in Bangkok. - The Bangkok Statement issued at the 15th RCC meeting highlights the commitments of delegates and observers of the meeting to call upon parties of the UN frameworks to uphold their commitments in implementing inclusive DRR and CR strategies and action plans at national and local level; strengthen their efforts to integrate gender equality in DRR and CR; engage with and build capacities to support inclusive resilience; and work towards promoting risk-informed development. - The Municipality of Bhraratpur, Chitwan Province of Nepal, and Municipality of Itogon, Benguet Province of the Philippines have recognized the importance of the program in their respective areas by jointly implementing the BRDR activities, and have expressed strong support to build the capacities of the municipalities.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

Reprogrammed funds to address COVID-19 The objective of the contributin is to contribute to the conditions of a stable and lasting peace in Colombia with a national, territorial, and rights-based perspective. The program will receive 63,8 MSEK of Sida funding between 2017-2021.

title.narrative: First Amendment to the Agreement between Sida and Diakonia

description.narrative: Context 2019 was a negative year in terms of security and protection for human rights defenders. New paramilitary groups continue attempting to control former FARC areas of influence and drug trade routes, consistently threatening social leaders that carry out their duties in these areas. The assassination of former FARC members does not seem to stop either, with the party reporting 72 murders in 2019. Likewise, hundreds of social leaders were murdered over the course of the year, a fact which continues to make Colombia the second deadliest place to be a human rights defender in the world. In October, the country held local elections, where unfortunately, only 19.7% of newly elected officials were women. In November, the country experienced nationwide social protests during the month of November. One of the agenda items in these protests was the murder of social leaders and the poor results in the implementation of the Peace Accord. Of particular relevance to the Diakonia program, the end of the peace talks with ELN created a deep humanitarian crisis in the department of Chocó. Increasing tensions between this group and paramilitaries not only resulted in threats to social leaders, but also in the violation of the freedom of expression of Community Councils and Indigenous Reservations as a way to undermine the strength of these organizational processes and prevent them from filing complaints on Human Rights and IHL violations. Female leaders are especially vulnerable. As a result, they must keep a low profile, restrict their movements and reinvent themselves to preserve their work and their family’s lives. In Cauca, the Government’s unwillingness to implement the Peace Accord also resulted in a greater presence of FARC dissidents eager to regain control over drug trade routes. ELN also continued carrying out their operations, while in August, the arrival of a new paramilitary group, the Autodefensas Gaitanistas de Colombia was also recorded. The government has responded by strengthening military presence in the area, however, there are reports of connivance between the former and the latter, thus leading to civilian mistrust in the Armed Forces, who are also accused of stigmatizing human rights defenders. Finally, in Magdalena Medio there was an increase in small criminal organizations linked to the AGC, who strengthened their incursion into urban centers. Social leaders reported threats, enforced disappearances, arbitrary detentions, and murders. Despite this grim scenario, gender, women’s and youth movements skyrocketed in the region, demonstrating the resilience of civil society even in the face of such danger. Summary of Results Diakonia and its partners demonstrated to civil society, media, State authorities and the international community that the situation faced by human rights defenders in Colombia is ever more dire. In the four areas pertaining to this program, Diakonia achieved the following results. Result Area 1: Human Rights for Peace and Environmental Justice There was strengthened dialogue between partners and the transitional justice institutions, elevating their capacity for political dialogue. Several of the Acuerdo Humanitario Ya reports were widely covered by media. Organizations worked towards strengthening 30 collective protection plans in Cauca and Magdalena Medio, whereas the Regional Protection Funds offered support to 57 human rights defenders. Partners maintained the judicial accountability for the protection of rights by placing legal action to protect youth arbitrarily detained during the November protests. One partner, MOVICE, requested JEP place cautionary measures on 16 sites where there are likely remains of missing persons. Partners participated in drafting of the the Business and Human Rights National Action Plan, led by the Government. Result Area 2: Gender Equality and Diversity Women’s organizations are increasingly playing an important role in the social demand for rights. Here are some of the main results achieved by Diakonia and its partners in this area: In Chocó, 4 female mayors, 3 representatives to the Departmental Assembly, and 31 Municipal Council Representatives were elected. All of them participated in the REDMUCHO School for Public Training, led by a Diakonia partner. Several partners successfully managed to have their public policy proposals included in Departmental agenda (Chocó), as well as included in the shadow report to CEDAW, which led to dialogue with public institutions. This was particularly the case with regards to the situation of LBT women flagged by Colombia Diversa. Strengthen action against gender-based violence, including the production of campaigns, documents, and reports on the matter. Results Area 3: Peace Negotiations and New Conflicts- Conflict and Justice Despite the ongoing conflict, the fractured talks between the Government and the ELN, Diakonia and its partners continued demanding a respect for IHL, promoting dialogue between the parties, and strengthening social movements that demand peace. 960 leaders built and took ownership over technical and conceptual tools to oversee the implementation of the ethnic chapter in the Peace Agreement. The Open Fund initiative supported 6 new projects that strengthened the work of the new transitional justice mechanisms created by the Peace Agreement. Diakonia partners managed to impact 5 National Action Plans for Regional Transformation (out of 16 prioritized by the government). Diakonia offered a training program for youth interested in peacebuilding through the Open Fund Initiative. Results Area 4: Independence and organizational sustainability for post-conflict These results areas are examples of internal achievements made within Diakonia to enhance its role as a support base for civil society organizations and strengthen itself internally as well. Internal trainings within Diakonia on democracy, transparency, and accountability to elevate its standing for the development of actions oriented towards Human Rights and Peacebuilding. Strategic planning exercises to expand its donor base. Increase Diakonia’s online presence. Acknowledge emotional exhaustion as a key factor when providing support to partners. Open Fund Initiative The Open Fund Initiative pilot was an idea crafted between Diakonia and Sida to provide support to grassroots organizations that might not otherwise be eligible for international cooperation resources. The Fund’s thematic areas were Human Rights, Peacebuilding, and Gender Equality. The fund was deemed a successful experiment. All 19 partners executed the funds properly, with a 99% and 100% execution ratio. Only one organization executed funds at 80%. Projects supported by the Fund had impacts on their specific topics, areas of influence, and target populations. Furthermore, this resource was positive in catalyzing small organizations’ actions, in many cases providing a much-needed support to enhancing M&E, accounting, and administrative skills. In several cases, it provided the only source of income to pay for salaries for persons who had previously worked on their causes pro bono. Despite their limited structures, many organizations demonstrated sharp focus in achieving the goals proposed in their projects with Diakonia. Mid-Term Evaluation During the first semester of 2019, Diakonia underwent a mid-term evaluation. The main findings of this exercise can be summarized in the following points: Relevance Due to contextual changes, the assumptions for the fulfillment of the scenarios varied. The problem is still relevant but requires further analysis, adaptation of the proposals and an enhancing the achievements. This is true not only at the level of national and international incidence in, but also with the civil society in the territories. What is imperative is that Diakonia activates its role as defender of the defenders and strengthen civil society with its well-structured theoretical approach. Diakonia, being an excellent donor, committed and consistent with its ethical stance towards human rights can help greatly to encourage the partners of its programme to face the current challenges. Partnerships established by the program at present, are less powerful than the one of its allies, who have been able to weave invaluable connections in a country where they wanted to annihilate the social movement. Diakonia at this time need to review its own role of recognition and legitimacy to perform an incidence and 'diplomacy' that will allow to improve the impact of their program by creating necessary bridges. Efficiency Although the Diakonia team delivers relevant information, reports of some partners are not delivered on time to Diakonia, this has improved, but sometimes these delays occur. The team spends much time preparing consolidated reports that do not result in an optimal reading of the impacts of the program and fail to adequately inform the Embassy of Sweden about effects and impacts obtained. Efficacy The program in general had no deviations or important changes, it has successfully executed a high percentage of what was planned. In terms of program efficacy Diakonia does not have a suitable methodology to measure progress, achievements and impacts. Impact The programme and the counterparts have transformed war-making ideas so that the public opinion understands that the defense of human rights in the peacebuilding process is necessary, legitimate and proactive. The team is excellent, very high level of competition, with ability to maneuver and understanding to the various territorial and national scenarios; but the departure of one of its officers has had increased the workload of the remaining staff. Sustainability The Diakonia team has the skills and qualities to guarantee sustainable processes. Headquarters and the Regional Office should reduce their multiple demands on the Colombia Office. On the other hand, the team should practice an efficient use of a good local monitoring system.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

title.narrative: COVID-19 UNDP Zimbabwe Resilience Building Fund 2017 - 2021
COVID-19 UNDP Zimbabwe Resilience Building Fund 2017 - 2021

description.narrative:
New/additional funds to address COVID-19 New/additional funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 The ZRBF aims to increase the resilience of households and communities in Zimbabwe experiencing poverty and extreme poverty and food insecurity, primarily at the rural level, with a strong focus of gender equality and the integration of women and youths in the programme. Additionally, the programme will aim to target a minimum of 800 000 individuals and communities particularly vulnerable to the impacts of climatic change. It must be noted that the ZRBF, with gender equality at the heart of its programming will aim to target a minimum of 400 000 women in its programming.
The expected results for the ZRBF, with the funding available as per 2015, is to enhance food security and livelihood diversification strategies of targeted communities that increase resilience to recurrent stresses/shocks. More specifically the ZRBF is expected to:
• Increase effective evidence based institutional, legislative and policy frameworks in place at national and sub-national levels for resilience
• Increase the absorptive, adaptive and transformative capacities to face shocks and the effects of climate change for approximately 800,000 people in vulnerable communities frequently exposed to multiple hazards in a total of estimated 20 of Zimbabwe’s 59 rural districts.
• Improved protection of household and community assets and decrease in annual economic losses due to effects of hazards and climate change
• A crisis modifier that can provide early warning and early action to reduce the impact of climate induced shocks in place for the Fund. (With the new planned budget allocation, a substantial increase in the target number of beneficiaries is estimated. While it is planned that 10-25% of programmable funds will be allocated to this result area, final beneficiaries number will be subject to further needs assessment and also based on the nature of the shocks/crises and scope of the planned response.)

Nya medel/medeltillägg för att bekämpa covid-19 Nya medel/medeltillägg för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Det här projektet stödjer UNDP:s Zimbabwe Resilience Building Fund (ZRBF) med totalt 75 miljoner SEK över tre år (2017-2020). Projektet relaterar till strategin för utvecklingssamarbete för Zimbabwe (2017-2021), befintlig och framtida portfölj gällande miljö och klimatförändringar och är relevant i förhållande till det utvecklingspolitiska ramverket. Programmet har också ett starkt fokus på jämställdhet.
ZRBF är utformad som en multigivarfond med en tidsram på fem år och en budget på minst 50 miljoner USD inom de första två åren. Projektets totala budget är 540 miljoner SEK, av vilket UNDP:s finansierar ca 10 miljoner SEK och resterande 530 miljoner SEK finansieras genom DFID och EU.
Det övergripande målet för ZRBF är att bidra till samhällens ökade kapacitet och motståndskraft (resiliens) att skydda sig från externa chocker och påfrestningar och därmed göra det möjligt för dem att också bidra till Zimbabwes ekonomiska tillväxt. ZRBF har tre huvudkomponenter sedan under uppstartsfasen, som började i maj 2015:
1. Producera bevismaterial för evidensbaserat beslutsfattande inom resiliens; 2. inrätta en multigivarfond till förmån för resiliensbyggande i Zimbabwe för att tillåta partners att enas kring ett Resilience Framework och principerna för att förbättra kapaciteten för anpassning, 3. inrätta en mekanism för riskfinansiering för att bidra till insatser som ökar resiliensen.
De förväntade resultaten för ZRBF, med tillgängliga medel sedan 2015, är att förbättra matsäkerheten och strategier för försörjningsdiversifiering som ökar motståndskraften mot återkommande påfrestningar/chocker.
ZRBF förväntas mer specifikt att:
• Stärka det institutionella, lagstiftande och politiska ramverket för resiliens. • Öka kapaciteten för anpassning och förändring för att kunna möta externa chocker och effekterna av klimatförändringar för uppskattningsvis 800 000 människor i sårbara samhällen, ofta utsatta för flertalet olika utmaningar i totalt 20 av Zimbabwes 59 distrikt • Minska de årliga ekonomiska förlusterna som beror på olika chocker och klimatförändringar. • Etablera en så kallad ”krismodifierare” som kan förmedla tidiga varningar och tidiga insatser för att minska påverkan från klimatframkallade chocker.
Antalet människor som förväntas nås av insatsen uppgår till hela 800 000.
Då ZRBF använder UNDP:s programbaserade tillvägagångssätt, baserat på landets egna prioriteringar anser ambassaden att bidraget ligger i linje med principerna för Parisdeklarationen och biståndseffektivitet. Det ger ambassaden en möjlighet för riktad respons för UNDP i genomförandet av strategin för 2017 till 2021. Det här är också en möjlighet att stärka gemensamma givarsamarbeten och dialog kring UNDP:s resultatområden gällande klimatförändringar och resiliens.

tag.narrative: 13.1 - Strengthen resilience and adaptive capacity to climate-related hazards and natural disasters in all countries.
13.1 - Stärka motståndskraften mot och förmågan till anpassning till klimatrelaterade faror och naturkatastrofer i alla länder.
13.2 - Integrate climate change measures into national policies, strategies and planning.
13.2 - Integrera klimatåtgärder i politik, strategier och planering på nationell nivå.

13.b - Främja mekanismer för att höja förmågan till effektiv klimatrelaterad planering och förvaltning i de minst utvecklade länderna, med särskilt fokus på kvinnor, ungdomar samt lokala och marginaliserade samhällen.

13.b - Promote mechanisms for raising capacity for effective climate change-related planning and management in least developed countries and small island developing States, including focusing on women, youth and local and marginalized communities.

2.4 - By 2030, ensure sustainable food production systems and implement resilient agricultural practices that increase productivity and production, that help maintain ecosystems, that strengthen capacity for adaptation to climate change, extreme weather, drought, flooding and other disasters and that progressively improve land and soil quality.

2.4 - Senast 2030 uppnå hållbara system för livsmedelsproduktion samt införa motståndskraftiga jordbruksmetoder som ökar produktiviteten och produktionen, som bidrar till att upprätthålla ekosystemen, som stärker förmågan till anpassning till klimatförändringar, extrema väderförhållanden, torka, översvämning och andra katastrofer och som successivt förbättrar mark- och jordkvaliteten.

5.a - Genomföra reformer för att ge kvinnor lika rätt till ekonomiska resurser, möjlighet att äga och kontrollera mark och andra former av egendom samt tillgång till finansiella tjänster, arv och naturresurser, i enlighet med nationell lagstiftning

5.a - Undertake reforms to give women equal rights to economic resources, as well as access to ownership and control over land and other forms of property, financial services, inheritance and natural resources, in accordance with national laws.
6.1 - By 2030, achieve universal and equitable access to safe and affordable drinking water for all.
6.1 - Senast 2030 uppnå allmän och rättvis tillgång till säkert och ekonomiskt överkomligt dricksvatten för alla.

7.b - By 2030, expand infrastructure and upgrade technology for supplying modern and sustainable energy services for all in developing countries, in particular least developed countries, small island developing States and landlocked developing countries, in accordance with their respective programmes of support.

7.b - Till 2030 bygga ut infrastrukturen och uppgradera tekniken för att leverera moderna och hållbara energitjänster till alla i utvecklingsländerna, i synnerhet de minst utvecklade länderna och små önationer under utveckling.

title.narrative: Second Amendment on Decision of Contribution

description.narrative: Under Component 1 During the first half of 2018 focus was directed towards analysis of capacity at district and national level to generate evidence, support to national surveys critical for resilience, as well as generation of resilience thematic case studies and technical notes. Implementation of capacity building activities was informed by the gaps identified during the capacity assessments under taken in November of 2016 and 2017 for first call and second call consortia. Key achievements during the period under review include ? Impact Evaluations: Baseline impact evaluation was conducted for five sampled projects under ZRBF namely ECRIMS, MELANA, PROGRESS, SIZIMELE and ZVA with data collection processes completed in mid-February 2018. Validation of baseline results was conducted in May 2018, ? Capacity building & Learning: During the reporting period, the following are key achievements:o In June 2018 Open Data Kit Level 2 advanced training was conducted for 30 government officials to further improve skills for data capturing during national surveys,o The 4th ZRBF Biannual Review and Lessons Learnt Workshop was successfully held in Harare from the 12th to the 14th of June 2018. The workshop was held under the theme, “Emerging Good Practices for Resilience Building”. The objectives were to share of good practices and discussion on how these can further be enhanced to contribute towards resilience building and identify critical gaps in current practices that need to be addressed during implementation of various activities. Over 90 delegates participated from all provinces and districts of ZRBF implementation were represented.o Commensurate with improving data capturing and analysis skills, second level SPSS training was also delivered to 50 MLARR officials in June 2018 for improved data entry, cleaning and analysis of the crop and livestock assessments,o On the 26th of March, MLARR and the ZRBF PMU facilitated a workshop on the validation of Irrigation Inventory and its implications on ZRBF programming,o The ZRBF PMU facilitated a district-to-district peer learning visit to Binga with 17 participants including government officials and Sizimele consortium members from Matobo and Insiza. The visit focused on local level planning for resilience building, good practices for artificial insemination, evidence generation capacities within the government departments and high frequency monitoring system functionality,o In support of evidence generation, ZRBF PMU handed over 8 high performance computers, 140 mini desktop computers, 70 GPS machines and 9 pH meters at national, provincial and district level. ? Performance Monitoring: The ZRBF PMU together with MLARR conducted performance monitoring visits to 6 districts namely Binga, Kariba, Mutoko, Zvishavane, Bubi and Matobo. In addition, ZRBF PMU facilitated and participated in Steering Committee biannual monitoring visit to Mwenezi and Chiredzi districts, ? The Resilience Measurement Technical Working Group inception and planning meeting was held in June 2018 with participation of ZRBF PMU and chaired by Food and Nutrition Council, ? Technical notes, support and platforms: With these regards, the technical note on Barriers to Small Grains Value Chains in Zimbabwe was published and disseminated to a wider audience. Furthermore, ZRBF supported the data verification exercise for the First Round of the Crop and Livestock Assessment. A combined report for the First and Second Round Crop and Livestock Assessments for the 2017/18 season was released by MLARR on the 9th of May 2018. MLARR and the ZRBF PMU undertook High Frequency Monitoring System sensitization mission to Mutoko, Mudzi, Mberengwa and Zvishavane. The main outcome of these sensitisation meetings was the commencement of data collection by the respective districts. Under component 2 During the reporting period, ZRBF consortia partners continued to implement planned activities. ? Disaster Risk Management (DRM) implementation and strengthening of DRM structures: With regards to DRM, the key planned activities were monitoring of DRM implementation (for 2016 consortia partners) and strengthening of DRM structures (for the 2017 consortia partners). Fifty nine out of eighty-four at risk communities (wards) (70.2%) had a disaster risk reduction (DRR) and/or integrated disaster reduction and adaptation in their strategy or action plan by the end of the reporting period. Consortia partners therefore continued to support the implementation of DRM plans. Communities have taken the lead and embarked on community led initiatives which has strengthened their ability to respond to emergencies. Continued support of these community led initiatives will see communities bouncing back better from shocks and stresses in a sustainable manner. ? High Frequency Monitoring (HFM): During the reporting period, the project teams and extension officers continued to track the HFM indicators. The data continued to be used for adaptive programming and the dissemination of advisories continued throughout the reporting period. ? Private Sector Engagement/Market Linkages and Financial Inclusion: ZRBF has noted a marked improvement in the number of private sector companies now collaborating with consortia partners although this still has to translate to tangible benefits to the project participants. In addition, some relationships are still fragile, characterized by suspicion and mistrust, thus pointing to a need to invest time in relationship building in addition to farmer training. There is still very little participation of the financial services sector. However, consortia partners are commended for bringing insurance companies on board. Efforts continue to be made to integrate ZRBF activities with other development partners operating in the districts. ? HEALTH/ WASH interventions: The ZRBF funded projects continue to collaborate with a wide range of stakeholders in delivery of HEALTH/ WASH interventions. In total, the ZRBF projects recorded 9 000 out of the planned 10573 (90%) households with access to safe drinking water and basic sanitation during the reporting period. ? Agricultural production and productivity: During the reporting period, the ZRBF through its seven consortia partners trained about 58 038 project participants out of a planned 58 881 (93.5%). Several training strategies were used, including classroom training, farmer field schools, demonstrations, visits to processing facilities and look and learn visits. Trainings focused on different thematic areas such as agronomy for various crops, climate smart agriculture, animal husbandry, fodder preservation, etc. ? Productive Infrastructure: Progress has been made in completion of infrastructure projects, 82 out of the planned 95 functional productive infrastructures were set up through ZRBF support. To improve quality and sustainability, ZRBF is in the process of engaging engineers to assist with quality assurance for infrastructure projects funded under ZRBF. ? Community safety nets: All ZRBF funded projects are promoting (Village Savings and Lending Associations (VSALs) which remain strong foundations for resilience building in the current economic context in rural areas. In addition, they provide financial services at a micro level. Funding of enterprises; food security, insurance and social capital are built within the VSAL methodology. Layering commodity groups on VSAL groups allows community members to take full ownership of activities and mature quickly as they use the already established group governance structures to their advantage in dealing with group dynamics. ? Enhanced Livelihoods: Entrepreneurship development is being promoted across consortia. The ZRBF funded projects continue with initiatives aimed at building an enabling environment as well as paying attention to cross cutting issues such as gender, child protection, HIV/AIDS, nutrition, and environment. ? Project participants registration & reach: The ZRBF PMU has organized technical working session to assist consortia with their databases and beneficiary registration, paying attention to layering, sequencing and integration of interventions as some consortia were struggling with these concepts. ? Technical assistance: The ZRBF PMU organized one on one meetings with consortia partners to address identified gaps, including: data quality assurance, infrastructure projects, private sector engagement, value for money, beneficiary registration matrix, and layering and sequencing of interventions. In addition, joint quarterly review meetings facilitated by the ZRBF PMU were designed to provide a platform for peer to peer learning. The review meetings included field visits and created opportunities for collaboration and sharing of experiences. Under component 3 ? Generating and utilization of high frequency monitoring system: Seventeen districts consistently reported on the 17 indicators for High Frequency Monitoring System except for Umguza which did not submit data in March. ? Crisis modifier mechanism: In March the crisis modifier was activated for Mwenezi, Chiredzi, Umzingwane, Umguza, Bubi, Nkayi, Kariba, Binga and Mbire. ECRAS, MELANA and ZVA consortia were invited to apply for funding from the crisis modifier mechanism to implement early action related activities. The Consortia Partners from BRACT, ECRIMS, PROGRESS and SIZIMELE, being in their first year of implementation, were advised on how to apply adaptive management to add and deprioritise activities in response to HFM system findings. More specific results include: •Problem Tree Analysis: To map the drivers, root causes and effects of decline in wellbeing outcomes to determine leverage points for domain change. •Correlation Analysis: To understand better the cross relationship between exposure to hazards, poverty, food insecurity and stunting. •Solution Tree Analysis: to determine the pathways through which resilience can be built: Resilience Through What? Including Gender, climate change and livelihoods analysis developed. •Theory of Change Developed: to articulate HOW and WHY the interventions will lead to the desired change. •Visibility and Communication strategy developed. •Capacity Building support being rolled out at national, province and district levels. •Analytical products: Multi Hazard maps; ENSO ANALYSIS for Zimbabwe; Barriers to small grains analysis; up-coming solutions; gender, climate chance and livelihoods analysis. •Data generation and analytics: 5 Databases developed and implemented in MLARR for improved quality and timeliness of data; MLARR central, provice and district level staff trained in ODK and SPSS; equipment for improved data management at all administrative levels. •Support to national surveys: •4 Zimvac process supported, since 2017 with inclusion of resilience components in the exercise – recently recognised at SADC level as best practise. •PICES process currently support with inclusion of resilience analysis. •Crop& livestock assessments supported. •National irrigation inventory supported with 5 provinces. •Resilience measurement and indicator guides. •14 High frequency monitoring bulletins. •Web-site, social media platforms. Absorptive Capacity Scenario planning for development of ward level resilience plans. Multi-Hazard Risk Analysis - Household Livelihood Security Assessment (HLSA) and Risk analysis for disaster risk management. Disaster Risk Management structures. Strengthen response capacity and early warning systems. Community fabric and safety nets i.e. communal seed banks, granaries, cash savings. Adaptive Capacity Improved crop, livestock and agroforestry production (Crop-livestock systems,) Creating Income (on farm & off-farm) generating opportunities Small scale productive infrastructure developments Improving community health and nutrition Markets and value chain development Transformative Capacity Improved social, agriculture and water service delivery addressing poverty and building resilience Integrate seasonal advisories with service provider outreach strategies and dissemination using mobile messaging platforms Develop and roll out a community scorecard for improved service delivery Communities engage duty bearers on provision of services •1,053,652 men and woman have benefited from July 2016 to July 2018. • 213 at risk wards with a disaster risk reduction and/or integrated disaster reduction and adaptation in their strategy. • 263 wards with disaster early warning and response (EWR) systems working effectively. •15262 households with access to safe drinking water and basic sanitation supported by ZRBF. •780 functional productive infrastructures developed. •23.6 % women or youth represented in decision making structures at ward and district levels in ZRBF project areas. •184 Agro-dealers capacitated to provide community based revolving supplies and market linkages to smallholder farmers. •2260 farmers participating in value addition of Non- Timber Forest Products (NTFPs). •27.5% of households adopting climate smart agricultural production technologies in year 1. •354 ISALS supported.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

By 2023 policies, strategies, plans, programmes and practices at national and sub-national levels taking on findings of SUMERNET's joint action and research which consider human rights, conflict sensitivity, gender inclusivity and poverty reduction .

Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Stockholm Environment Institutes Asien-kontor (SEI Asien) har på uppdrag av det regionala Sustainable Mekong Research Network (SUMERNET) inkommit med en ansökan till ambassaden för fortsatt stöd i fem år till SUMERNETs nästa fas, kallad SUMERNET 4 All. Programmet kommer under nästa tioårsperiod att fokusera sitt arbete på det strategiska målet "Minska vattenosäkerheten för alla, särskilt fattiga, marginaliserade och socialt utsatta grupper av kvinnor och män i Mekongregionen". För den initiala femårsperioden, från 2018 till 2023, är det ansökta beloppet från Sverige 60 miljoner kronor. Forskningsprogrammet kommer att genomföras i Sydostasien / Mekong-regionen (Myanmar, Thailand, Kambodja, Laos, Vietnam och två provinser i Kina)
Insatsen syftar till att bidra till en hållbar utveckling i Mekongregionen genom att stärka kunskapsbaserade politiska processer och överbrygga avståndet mellan vetenskap och politik. SUMERNET åstadkommer detta genom att välja forskningsfrågor som är direkt relevanta för aktuella politiska debatter, engagera beslutsfattare i alla aspekter av sin verksamhet och bygga kapacitet för hållbar utveckling genom mentorstöd, workshops och annan verksamhet. SUMERNET 4 All kommer att fokusera sina ansträngningar på tre specifika forskningstema inklusive (1) tillgång till vatten, rättigheter och fördelning under vattenbrist, (2) styrning och hantering av översvämningskatastrofer och (3) gränsöverskridande vattensystem. SUMERNET betonar också samarbete, nätverkande och kunskapsdelning, samt samarbete mellan aktörer i olika länder genom projekt och evenemang och syftar därmed till att stärka forskning och politiskt engagemang i hela regionen.
Insatsens totala budget är 60 miljoner kronor. Cirka 28 miljoner kronor kommer att användas till forskningsverksamhet, cirka 15 miljoner kronor till flerpartssamverkan och ca 6 miljoner kronor till kommunikation och dissemination av resultat.

Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 Stockholm Environment Institute’s Asia Centre (SEI Asia) has on behalf of the regional Sustainable Mekong Research Network (SUMERNET) submitted a proposal to the Embassy for continued support for five years to SUMERNET’s next phase, called SUMERNET 4 All. The program will over a ten-year period focus its efforts on the strategic goal “Reducing water insecurities for all in particular for the poor, marginalized and socially vulnerable groups of women and men in the Mekong Region’’. For the initial five-year period, from 2018 to 2023, the amount requested from Sweden is 60 million SEK. The research program will be carried out in South East Asia/Mekong Region (Myanmar, Thailand, Cambodia, Laos, Vietnam and two provinces in China)
The intervention aims to contribute to sustainable development in the Mekong Region by strengthening knowledge-based policy processes and a key aspect of SUMERNET’s work is to bridge science and policy. SUMERNET achieves this by choosing research questions that are directly relevant to current policy debates, engaging decision-makers in all aspects of their activities, and building capacity for sustainable development through mentoring support, workshops and other activities. SUMERNET 4 All will focus its effort on three specific research themes including (1) water access, rights & allocation in times of scarcity, (2) governance and management of flood disaster risks and (3) transboundary interactions with water systems. SUMERNET also emphasises collaboration, networking and knowledge-sharing, connecting partners in different countries through projects and events thereby aiming at continually strengthening research and policy engagement across the region.
The intervention’s total budget is 60 million SEK out of wich approximately 28 MSEK will be used for research activities, approximately 15 MSEK to multistakeholder activities and approximately 6 MESK will be used for communications and outreach.

tag.narrative: 13.b - Främja mekanismer för att höja förmågan till effektiv klimatrelaterad planering och förvaltning i de minst utvecklade länderna, med särskilt fokus på kvinnor, ungdomar samt lokala och marginaliserade samhällen.

17.6 - Enhance North-South, South-South and triangular regional and international cooperation on and access to science, technology and innovation and enhance knowledge-sharing on mutually agreed terms, including through improved coordination among existing mechanisms, in particular at the United Nations level, and through a global technology facilitation mechanism.

17.6 - Stärka nord–syd-samarbetet, syd–syd-samarbetet och det regionala och internationella trepartssamarbetet kring och tillgången till vetenskap, teknik och innovation samt öka kunskapsutbytet på gemensamt överenskomna villkor, inklusive genom förbättrad samordning mellan befintliga mekanismer, i synnerhet på FN-nivå, och genom en global mekanism för teknikfrämjande.
5.1 - Avskaffa alla former av diskriminering av alla kvinnor och flickor överallt
5.1 - End all forms of discrimination against all women and girls everywhere.

6.3 - By 2030, improve water quality by reducing pollution, eliminating dumping and minimizing release of hazardous chemicals and materials, halving the proportion of untreated wastewater and substantially increasing recycling and safe reuse globally.

6.3 - Till 2030 förbättra vattenkvaliteten genom att minska föroreningar, stoppa dumpning och minimera utsläpp av farliga kemikalier och material, halvera andelen obehandlat avloppsvatten och väsentligt öka återvinningen och en säker återanvändning globalt.

6.4 - By 2030, substantially increase water-use efficiency across all sectors and ensure sustainable withdrawals and supply of freshwater to address water scarcity and substantially reduce the number of people suffering from water scarcity.

6.4 - Till 2030 väsentligt effektivisera vattenanvändningen inom alla sektorer samt säkerställa hållbara uttag och en hållbar försörjning med sötvatten för att angripa vattenbristen och väsentligt minska det antal människor som lider av vattenbrist.
6.5 - By 2030, implement integrated water resources management at all levels, including through transboundary cooperation as appropriate.
6.5 - Senast 2030 genomföra en integrerad förvaltning av vattenresurser på alla nivåer, när så är lämpligt genom gränsöverskridande samarbete.

description.narrative: As of November 2020 the SUMERNET4ALL has been operating for slightly more than 2 years. SUMERNET4ALL is the fourth agreement between Sida and the Sustainable Mekong Research Network hosted by the Stockholm Environmet Institute in Asia. SUMERNET is an initiative for research and policy engagement bringing together research partners working on sustainable development in the countries of the Mekong Region: Cambodia, Lao PDR, Myanmar, Thailand and Vietnam. China is also included in SUMERNET4ALL, however the participation of Chinese researchers in research activities is dependent upon them securing their own research funding. This conclusion on performance covers the period from June 2019 until November 2020. The covid-19 has significant consequences for SUMERNET4ALL. The first case of covid-19 outside China was detected in Thailand in early January 2020, and by late March most countries in the region had imposed strict travel restrictions to limit the spread of the virus. As of November 2020 most international travel is restricted in the region, and in some countries (e.g. Myanmar) there are restrictions on domestic movement and activities. SUMERNET4ALL was originally designed to be dependent upon mobility of researchers and stakeholders to move across national borders in order to attend meeting and trainings, and to carry-out transboundary research projects. As such, the covid-19 has had a major impact on the network and its activities. Despite the challenges associated with the covid-19 pandemic, SUMERNET4ALL has shown a strong capacity to adapt to the new situation, not least through a shift to online video-conferencing and other Internet communication and collaboration tools. The network has also worked together with researchers in the region to reflect upon new challenges and opportunities for research that are posed by the covid-19 pandemic, and to share the lessons learned (see https://www.sumernet.org/story/5-tips-for-success-in-delivering-research-projects-during-covid). These efforts are themselves important results. The challenges and uncertainties associated with the covid-19 pandemic have also created some unexpected delays in the planned activities. For example, field visits by SUMERNET Advisors and Secretariat staff to follow-up and support ongoing projects have been delayed due to travel restrictions. Likewise, the shift from in-person to on-line activities has caused some delays. Further examples of results achieved by SUMERNET4ALL during the period under review include: - Twelve collaborative research grants have been competetively awarded to multi-country/transboundry research projects. Four projects address water access, rights and allocation in times of scarcity. Six projects address governance and management of flood disaster risks, and two projects address transboundary interactions with water systems, including projects measuring the impact of atmospheric pollution deposition on water quality and its influence on community water use. All twelve projects integrate gender into the research, and minority groups' access to water resources. - One research grant was competetively awarded to collaborative research across five countries for a groundwater integrated regional assessment. - SUMERNET has designed and implemented an ethical review process for research projects that receive funding. Thus far, 13 projects have been successfully reviewed. - One research grant was competetively awarded in a special call for a collaborative research project on water insecurities during the covid-19 pandemic. - SUMERNET has seen an improvement in the rate of participation of its members in the elections of steering committee members. - A newly designed website (www.sumernet.org) was launched that includes new material such as interviews, journalistic stories, podcasts, short films, and summaries of network activities. - SUMERNET4ALL has made rapid progress towards meeting or exceeding its target indicators. Amongst these are included the proportion of young researchers involved in SUMERNET projects (target 35%, achieved 49%), the proportion of research projects and joint actions which engage with women/gender organizations as the researchers or boundary partners or target beneficiaries (target 35%, achieved 50%), and the proportion of research projects which address environmental rights in their key research questions (target 15%, achieved 60%) (see 2019 Annual Narrative Report for more information).
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

title.narrative: World Bank Trust Fund Cash Transfers

description.narrative: Objective, outcomes and outputs of the intervention The Multi-Donor Trust Fund (MDTF) will expand and further strengthen the country’s social protection programmes and instruments. Outcome 1:By 2021, increased social protection coverage per capita in the poorest provinces Output 1: By 2021, at least 176.500 poor households in the poorest provinces benefit from social protection programs Outcome 2:Improved quality of service delivery for the payments of cash transfers Output 2.1: Increased share of payments delivered by private service providers Output 2.2:e-INAS gradually being used for the registration and management of SP beneficiaries Between 14 000 and 114 000 households (families) will be reached byt the program as beneficiaries. The numbers may radically increase during 2019 as there are plans for a rapid response to the cyclone hit areas.

Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Stöd under 2019-2022 med totalt 75 miljoner SEK till utbyggnad av nationella sociala kontantstöd via Världsbankens Multi Donor Trust Fund, med fokus på att registrera fler förmånstagare, öka bidragsbeloppen (socialbidrag, barnbidrag, beredskapsarbete m.m.) samt stärka kapaciteten på socialförsäkringsmyndigheten INAS. Total budget för programmet är ca 180 miljoner SEK och andra givare är Storbritannien och Nederländerna. Det svenska bidraget uppgår till ca 41 procent an total budget. Fonden är aktiv sedan slutet av 2018.
Insatsen förväntas bidra till effektiva och transparenta utbetalningar samt till att vidareutveckla registret över förmånstagare (e-INAS ). Stödet är ett av de insatser i den svenska portföljen som tydligt kommer att svara mot de effekter som cyklonen IDAI medfört i de centrala delarna av landet. Minst 18 500 hushåll kommer att nås av insatsen, en siffra som kan komma att öka dramatiskt då fler givare kommer in med särskilt stöd till cyklondrabbade områden.

Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 Support during 2019-2022 with a total sum of 75 million SEK to scale-up the national social cash transfer system through a World Bank Multi Donor Trust Fund. Total budget is ca 180 million SEK, and other donors are UK and the Netherlands. Swedish share around 41 percent of total budget. The fund is active since end of 2018.
Focus is on scaling up cash transfers (social cash transfers, child grant, public works salaries) and on increasing the number of beneficiaries. The contribution is expected to strengthen INAS, the agency for social security, assure an efficient and transparent payment system and develop the beneficary registry (e-INAS). The support is one of the contributions that will reply to the negative effects of the cyclone IDAI in the central parts of the country.
At least 18 500 households will be reached by the intervention, a number toat may increase dramatically as more donors are coming in with specific support to mitigate for the effects of the cyclones.

New/additional funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 Support during 2019-2022 with a total sum of 75 million SEK to scale-up the national social cash transfer system through a World Bank Multi Donor Trust Fund. Total budget is ca 180 million SEK, and other donors are UK and the Netherlands. Swedish share around 41 percent of total budget. The fund is active since end of 2018.
Focus is on scaling up cash transfers (social cash transfers, child grant, public works salaries) and on increasing the number of beneficiaries. The support is one of the contributions that will reply to the negative effects of the cyclone IDAI in the central parts of the country.
At least 18 500 households will be reached by the intervention, a number toat may increase dramatically as more donors are coming in with specific support to mitigate for the effects of the cyclones.
