description.narrative: In the last six months, IDLO focused on strengthening institutional capacity of the Judiciary, the National Council on Administration of Justice (NCAJ) and other relevant justice sector actors, improve access to justice through reduction of case backlog; enhanced quality of legal frameworks for access to justice, improved linkages between formal and informal justice systems; and improved coordination of justice actors under the NCAJ leadership. The follwoing are some of the results that have been realised: 1. Enhanced access to justice through reduced case backlog in the Court of Appeal: IDLO supported reduction of the backlog in the Court of Appeal (COA) through support to service weeks and circuit visits to court stations where the COA does not ordinarily sit. The planned service week in March for the Kisumu Law courts was disrupted by theGovernment directive for nationwide lockdown. This did not affect the matters that had been set for hearing, as all the 62 matters scheduled for hearing were heard and determined through video-conferencing. From April 2020, COA hearings were virtual. As of June 2020, 219 appeal cases have been heard and determined and 213 rulings/ judgements delivered. Virtual hearings have ensured reduction of appeal case backlog and continuity of administration of justice during the pandemic. 2. Enhanced access to information on ongoing automation of judicial processes: Due to the effects of COVID-19 and the need to address emerging justice needs, IDLO supported the Judiciary’s Directorate of Public Affairs and Communications (DPAC) to run media public announcements and television infomercials in June 2020. The infomercials provided information to citizens on how to access the courts virtually for E-filing of cases, E-payment of court fees, virtual hearing of matters and delivery of rulings and judgments. This dissemination of information has also helped to subvert the misinformation on how the courts were operating during the pandemic, especially amongst litigants. 3. Civil Procedure (Amendment) Rules gazetted for implementation: IDLO supported development of the Civil Procedure (Amendment) Rules in 2019, through a Legislative Drafter in the Rules Committee to support the draftingand validation of pending rules. However, the finalised Rules had been pending review and gazettement by the Office of the Attorney General (OAG). On 22 February 2020, the Civil Procedure (Amendment) Rules were finally gazetted for implementation. The Rules simplify processes in the handling of civil matters and provide clarity on provisions of the Civil Procedure Act that have overtime been interpreted differently by the different courts. Full implementation ofthe Rules alongside the Act will accelerate adjudication of civil matters and contribute to reduction of case backlog in the courts currently handling civil cases. 4. Guidelines for implementation of the Access to Information Act developed and adopted: IDLO partnered with the Commission on Administration of Justice (CAJ) to develop Guidelines to aid implementation of Access to Information Act, 2016. This was through stakeholder consultations with the CAJ, various Government officesincluding the Office of the Attorney General (OAG), the Kenya Law Reform Commission (KLRC), Ministry of Information, Kenya National Registration Bureau of Statistics, and CSOs. 5. Framework for the implementation of the Legal Audit Report developed: IDLO supported KLRC and the Council of Governors (COG) to develop the Implementation Framework for the Legal Audit Report, as a road map for implementation of County level policy, legislative and administrative reforms with a view to strengthening devolution in Kenya. The Framework developed to operationalise the findings of the Legal Audit of the National and County policies and laws developed in 2019.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Oxfam GB har till Sveriges ambassad i Bangkok inkommit med en ansökan om stöd till en andra fas av programmet "Gender Transformative and Responsible Agribusiness Investments in South East Asia II", GRAISEA II (2018-2023). Programmets övergripande mål är: att stärka kvinnor och mäns roll och möjligheter inom jordbrukssektorn, genom att bidra till ändrade affärsmodeller och normer, samt att främja inkluderande värdekedjor, vilka ökar kvinnors ekonomiska egenmakt, ökar motståndskraft mot klimatförändringar, främjar mänskliga rättigheter och en rättvisare handel. Programmet fokuserar på två värdekedjor, ris och räkor, och omfattar fem länder; Pakistan, Vietnam, Kambodja, Indonesien och Filippinerna.
GRAISEA II bygger på resultat och lärdomar från första fasen (51020155), vilken startade 2015. Programmet är mer fokuserat vad gäller antal värdekedjor och länder än GRAISEA I, och antalet företag och privata aktörer som bidrar till programmet har närtill tredubblats. Programmet kommer verka på tre nivåer; 1) på producentnivå för att stärka kapaciteten hos marginaliserade ris- och räkproducenter, 2) på privatsektornivå för att få företagen att ändra sina affärsmodeller och 3) på politisk nivå för att bidra till ett ramverk som förbättrar villkoren för marginaliserade grupper och småproducenter.
Stödet till de regionala plattformarna Asian Seafood Improvement Collaborative (ASIC) och Sustainable Rice Platform (SRP) kommer att fortsätta. Genom att bidra till att genomföra rekommendationer och standarder från dessa organisationer kommer negativa miljökonsekvenser av jordbruket minska och verksamheten inom de aktuella värdekedjorna blir mer motståndskraftiga mot klimatförändringar.
Programmet kommer att stödja småskaliga lantbrukare och deras organisationer för att öka produktiviteten, uppfylla branschstandarder, anpassa sig till klimatförändringar, förbättra marknadstillträde och handel samt stärka kvinnors roll och ekonomiska egenmakt. GRAISEA II kommer också verka på politisk nivå med lokala och nationella regeringar och med regionala ASEAN kommittéer för att bidra till ett ramverk som värnar om företagande och mänskliga rättigheter (med särskilt fokus på ekonomiska rättigheter och rätt till arbete), främjar tillväxten för små och medelstora företag (SMEs) och uppmuntrar antagandet av inkluderande och ansvarsfulla affärsmodeller som bidrar till kvinnors ekonomiska egenmakt och ökar jordbrukets motståndskraft mot klimatförändringar.
Programmets relevans ur ett rättighetsperspektiv avser främst ekonomiska aspekter och jämställdhet. En viktig del i programmet är att få småbönder och producenter, med särskilt fokus på kvinnor, att bättre förstå sina rättigheter och öka sin förmåga att påverka privata sektorn och staten och dra bättre nytta av handeln för att uppnå inkluderande tillväxt.
Programmets totala budget för treårsperioden är 89,3 MSEK, varav Sida kommer att bidra med 79,9 MSEK och partners från privat sektor med resterande.

Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 Oxfam has applied to the Embassy of Sweden in Bangkok for funding of a second phase of the programme Gender Transformative and Responsible Agribusiness Investments in South East Asia II, GRAISEA II (2018-2023). The overall objective of the programme is: Opportunities for marginalised women and men in the agriculture sector are transformed through a shift in business practices and norms, promoting inclusive value chains and business models that drive women's economic empowerment (WEE), climate resilience, human rights and fair opportunities for producers. The programme focuses two value-chains, rice and shrimps, and covers five countries; Pakistan, Vietnam, Cambodia, Indonesia, and the Philippines.
GRAISEA II builds on results and lessons learned from the first phase (51020155), which started 2015. It is more focused, in terms of number of value-chains and geographical scope, than GRAISEA I and the number of contributing private sector actors has nearly tripled. The programme will promote the scaling-up of inclusive and responsible business models and practices and works across three levels; 1) at producer level to strengthen the capacity of marginalised rice and shrimp producers, 2) at private sector level to get companies to change business practices and 3) at policy level to establish a progressive policy framework.
It will continue to support and improve the work of the regional Multi-Stakeholder Initiatives (MSIs); the Asian Seafood Improvement Collaborative (ASIC) and Sustainable Rice Platform (SRP). By contributing to, and implementing, recommendations and standards of these MSIs, environmental degradation will be reduced and small-scale farmers and value chains will be more resilient towards climate change.
The programme will strengthen the collective action in the shrimp and rice value-chains and support farmer groups and their members to increase productivity, meet sector standards, adapt to climate change, facliitate market access and strengthen the role of women and WEE. GRAISEA II will also, jointly with its partners, work at policy level with local and national governments and regional ASEAN bodies to create policy frameworks that safeguard business and human rights, promote the growth of Small and Medium Enterprises (SMEs), and encourage the adoption of inclusive and responsible business models that drive WEE and support climate change resilience.
The human rights perspective of the programme relates mainly to economic aspects, business, and gender equality. Empowerment of small scale producers, with a specific focus on women, to better understand their rights and to develop their capacity to influence government and the private sector for inclusive markets and growth is at the core of the programme.
The programmes total budget for the three year period is 89.3 MSEK out of which Sida will provide 79.9 MSEK and partners from private sector the remaining share.

The overall objective of GRAISEA II is: Opportunities for marginalized women and men in the agriculture sector are transformed, through a shift in business practices and norms, promoting inclusive value chains and business models that drive women's economic empowerment, climate resilience, human rights, and fair opportunities for producers. Expected results and outcomes are as follows: 1) Women and men small-scale producers are able to participate and benefit fairly from economic opportunities in agriculture and seafood value chains in Vietnam, Cambodia, Indonesia and Pakistan. Confidence, voice and agency of women will be strengthened through technical support, development of "safe spaces" and household approaches so that women gain greater economic benefits. Producer groups will be strengthened in order to understand and apply relevant standards, make better deals, develop strategies to address climate change, understand market requirements, influence market actors and link up to private enterprises. 2) Within the agriculture and seafood value chains, market actors deliver opportunities that integrate small producers, promote women's economic empowerment and support climate change resilience. The private sector puts into practice inclusive models that support women's economic empowerment and climate resilience. SMEs connect small producers fairly to markets and build women's economic empowerment. Multi Stakeholder Initiatives (MSI) at national and regional levels facilitate the wider use of business practices that support inclusively, women's economic empowerment and climate resilience. 3) Enabling environment for business, human rights and inclusive agricultural investment that supports women's economic empowerment and climate resilience. National governments adopt business and human rights policy, and policy that promotes and inclusive agricultural sector that supports women's economic empowerment and climate resilience. ASEAN adopts policy and frameworks that promote business and human rights and support SME investment that promotes women's economic empowerment and climate resilience.

tag.narrative: 1.4 - By 2030, ensure that all men and women, in particular the poor and the vulnerable, have equal rights to economic resources, as well as access to basic services, ownership and control over land and other forms of property, inheritance, natural resources, appropriate new technology and financial services, including microfinance.

1.4 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att alla män och kvinnor, i synnerhet de fattiga och de utsatta, har lika rätt till ekonomiska resurser, tillgång till grundläggande tjänster, möjlighet att äga och kontrollera mark och andra former av egendom samt tillgång till arv, naturresurser, lämplig ny teknik och finansiella tjänster, inklusive mikrokrediter.
13.1 - Strengthen resilience and adaptive capacity to climate-related hazards and natural disasters in all countries.
13.1 - Stärka motståndskraften mot och förmågan till anpassning till klimatrelaterade faror och naturkatastrofer i alla länder.

2.3 - By 2030, double the agricultural productivity and incomes of small-scale food producers, in particular women, indigenous peoples, family farmers, pastoralists and fishers, including through secure and equal access to land, other productive resources and inputs, knowledge, financial services, markets and opportunities for value addition and non-farm employment.

2.3 - Till 2030 fördubbla jordbrukets produktivitet och inkomster för småskaliga livsmedelsproducenter, i synnerhet kvinnor, ursprungsfolk, familjejordbrukare, boskapsskötande nomader samt fiskare, inklusive genom säker och lika tillgång till mark, andra produktionsresurser och insatsvaror, kunskap, finansiella tjänster och marknader samt möjligheter till värdeskapande och sysselsättning utanför jordbruket.

2.4 - By 2030, ensure sustainable food production systems and implement resilient agricultural practices that increase productivity and production, that help maintain ecosystems, that strengthen capacity for adaptation to climate change, extreme weather, drought, flooding and other disasters and that progressively improve land and soil quality.

2.4 - Senast 2030 uppnå hållbara system för livsmedelsproduktion samt införa motståndskraftiga jordbruksmetoder som ökar produktiviteten och produktionen, som bidrar till att upprätthålla ekosystemen, som stärker förmågan till anpassning till klimatförändringar, extrema väderförhållanden, torka, översvämning och andra katastrofer och som successivt förbättrar mark- och jordkvaliteten.

5.4 - Erkänna och värdesätta obetalt omsorgs- och hushållsarbete genom att tillhandahålla offentliga tjänster, infrastruktur och socialt skydd samt genom att främja delat ansvar inom hushållet och familjen, i enlighet med vad som är nationellt lämpligt.

5.4 - Recognize and value unpaid care and domestic work through the provision of public services, infrastructure and social protection policies and the promotion of shared responsibility within the household and the family as nationally appropriate.
5.5 - Ensure women’s full and effective participation and equal opportunities for leadership at all levels of decision-making in political, economic and public life.
5.5 - Tillförsäkra kvinnor fullt och faktiskt deltagande och lika möjligheter till ledarskap på alla beslutsnivåer i det politiska, ekonomiska och offentliga livet.

9.3 - Increase the access of small-scale industrial and other enterprises, in particular in developing countries, to financial services, including affordable credit, and their integration into value chains and markets.

9.3 - Öka tillgången för småskaliga industriföretag och andra företag, i synnerhet i utvecklingsländerna, till finansiella tjänster, inklusive överkomliga krediter, samt deras integrering i värdekedjor och marknader.

description.narrative: The intervention started August 2018 with an inception period up to and including November 2018. During the inception period detailed project plans were completed, partners assessed, and systems and frameworks developed preparing for and guiding the implementation. Examples are financial guidelines, results framework, communication stategy and reporting formats. Weaknessess identified in GRAISEA 1, both by Oxfam and in the special review conducted by Moore Stephens, have been adressed to ensure a firm foundation for GRAISEA 2. During year 1 the PMU signed contracts/agreements with country teams and national and regional partners and most partners had 6-8 months to deliver on the work plans. Diagnostics relating to gender and climate change in the different value chains have been done. The main results achieved during year 1 relate to ensuring a firm foundation for the implementation of the intervention. Several activity targets were not met due to impementation delays and it is assessed both by Oxfam and Sida, that some targets set for year 1 were overambitious. 1) Progress is on track in Vietnam where producer groups have been engaged to increase their capacity. Groups both in rice and shrimp value chains have changed operations, and ameneded or developed group regulations, that strengthen the role of women. Progress is also on track in Indonesia while in Pakistan and Cambodia results are mixed. Meeting targets for women's participation has been a challenge in most countries and Oxfam assess that this is due to social norms and household duties which have hindered women participation. 2) Also in this result area, progress is better in Vietnam than in the other countries where there is a strong willingness from private companies to incorporate inclusive business models and six companies have signed contracts with nine farmer groups showing committment to support WEE and CSR in their supply chains. In Pakistan, one private sector company has started programs to include training for women, day-care for children and medical support. The regional partners, ASIC and CSR Asia have succeeded in building partnerships with market actors, trained staff to engage with the private sector, explore inclusive business opportunities in the value chains and map companies for further engagement. 3) The influencing work has started off with many different interventions ongoing by the different partners such as Asian Seafood Improvement Collaborative, Institute for Social Entrepreneurship and Women's Economic Empowerment Transformational Initiatives in Agricultural Value Chains. Results at national and regional policy level haven not yet been achieved. In addition to the Narrative report, Oxfam submitted a document presenting a Summary of Adaptations made to the year 2 activity plan. The adaptations are based on the lessons, challenges and opportunities idetified in year 1 and explains how plans have been adapted for year 2.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

Genom att använda det trematiska stödets modalitet, kommer Sidas stöd vara till "One UN Programme and Common Budgetary Framework BiH 2015-2019"samt den gemensamma arbetsplanen för 2017-2018 för pelare 1-Rättssäkerhet och mänsklig säkerhet och pelare 3- Social inkludering. Sverige kommer stötta barnskyddsprogrammet, som inkluderas under pelare 1 med resultat 1.2 ‘ Barn i riskzonen, barnoffer och vittnen till brott, barn som deltagande i civila och administrativa förfaranden och barn i konflikt med lagen får bättre servis och skydd’: och under pelare tre med resultat 10 ‘Till 2019, stärkta skyddssystem för att förhindra och reagera på fall av våld, misshandel, exploatering eller försummande av barn, institutionalisering inkluderat’ och resultat 10.1‘Stärka barn och deras föräldrars kapacitet att kräva barnrättsorganisationer ’ och 10.2 ‘att aktörer som utför tjänster är bättre utrustade att leverera barnskyddstjänster ’. Using the thematic support modality, the Sida support will be to the "One UN Programme and Common Budgetary Framework BiH 2015-2019" as well as the Joint Work Plans for 2017-2018 for Pillar 1-Rule of Law and Human Security and Pillar 3 Social Inclusion. Sweden will support the Child Protection programme which is included under Pillar 1 with Output 1.2 "Children at risk, child victims and witnesses of crime, children as parties in civil and administrative proceedings and children in conflict with the law better served and protected and under Pillar 3 with Outcome 10 "By 2019, child protection systems are strenghtened to prevent and respond to cases of violence, abuse, exploitation and neglect of children, including institutionalization and Outputs 10.1 Stregthened children and their families capacity to demand child protection services and 10.2 Service providers better equipped to deliver child protection services.

New/additional funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 UNICEF has applied to Sida for funding of 15 million SEK to carry out the implementation of UNICEF's activities within the thematic area "Child Protection" in BiH as part of the UNICEF Strategic Plan 2018-2021 and as outlined in the UNICEF Country Programme Document 2015-2020 in Bosnia and Herzegovina.
The objectives of the Programme are: -- By 2019, an increased number of boys and girls use a continuum of child protection services aimed at preventing and adequately responding to violence, neglect and abuse and family separation, and equitable access to justice is strengthened for all children. -- Strengthened children and their families’ capacity to demand child protection services -- Service providers better equipped to deliver child protection services -- Children at- risk, child victims and witnesses of crime, children as parties in civil and administrative proceedings and children in conflict with the law better served and protected

Nya medel/medeltillägg för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 UNICEF har ansökt hos Sida för 15 miljoner SEK i finansiering för att utföra implementeringen av UNICEF:s aktiviteter inom det tematiska området ”Child Protection” i BiH som en del av UNICEF:s strategiska plan 2018-2021 och som skissades i UNICEF Country Program Document 2015-2020 i Bosnien och Hercegovina.
Målen för programmet är: - Till 2019, ett ökat antal flickor och pojkar använder ett kontinuum av tjänster inom barnskydd riktade att förhindra och ge adekvat respons på våld, försummande, missförhållanden och familjeseparation, och att rättvis tillgång till rättvisa för alla barn stärks. - Stärka barnen och deras familjers kapacitet att kräva barnskyddstjänster. - Att service givare är bättre utrustad att leverera barnskyddstjänstera. - Att barn i riskzonen, barn som är offer och vittnen till brott, barn som är del av civilrättsliga och administrativa framfaranden och barn i konflikt med lagen är bättre omhändertagna och skyddade.

description.narrative: The Conclusion on Performance is made based on annual 2019 Country Thematic Report, as primary source of information. The report outlines key results for 2019, demonstrating what appears to be very good outreach on both the beneficiary side and the service provider side. Attached to the thematic report is a Result framework with indicators. Programme indicators are reported as being on track. There are only 5 outcome and context specific indicators bIn addition to the thematic result framework, UNICEF submitted a result monitoring frameworks which UNICEF uses particularly for the SDC Justice for Children phase 3 project, which is complementary to the thematic support financed by Sida. The result table is especially developed for Juvenile Justice (OMS table). This result monitoring frameworks is also showing clear progress against baselines established in 2016, although data availability is a problem particularly for juvenile recividism. Nevertheless, the OMS data are showing very good outreach, way beyond baselines established for secondary prevention programmes (number of school children covered by the programme) UNICEF also submitted a separate report on the IT Girls Initiative which is implemented in partnership with UNDP and UN Women. The initiative partnered with 10 schools in eight cities in BIH. The first Network of Women in ICT was established in BIH, bringing together 29 ICT experts.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

description.narrative: New/additional funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 Sida supports UNFPA's country program in Sudan through a non-earmarked programme support with SEK 45 million in period between 2017-2020. The total budget of the country programme 2018-2021 is approximately USD 40 million. The country programme is iplemented within three strategic outcome areas: sexual and reproductive health, gender equality and women's empowerment and population dynamics. The overall goal of the UNFPA country programme for Sudan is to reduce maternal deaths and disabilities through an integrated approach to sexual and eproductive health, family planning and prevention and response to gender-based violence. The programme seeks to strengthen capacities of health ministries and civil society partners at federal and priority state level. The objectives of the programme include to ensure access to high-quality sexual and reproductive services, family planning services, and preventing and responding to gender-based violence, while also increasing national capacities for data production and analysis. UNFPA's country programme includes both development and humanitarian interventions. Humanitarian needs in this context are often protracted and require a flexible approach that supports both development and humanitarian assistance.

Nya medel/medeltillägg för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Sida stödjer UNFPAs landprogram i Sudan genom ett icke-öronmärkt programstöd på 45 miljoner SEK under perioden 2017-2020. Landprogrammets totala budget är ca 40 miljoner USD under en programperiod på fyra år. Landprogrammet implementeras inom tre strategiska områden: sexuell och reproduktiv hälsa, jämställdhet och kvinnors egenmakt samt befolkningsutveckling. Det övergripande målet för UNFPAs landprogram i Sudan är att minska mödradödlighet genom ett integrerat stöd till sexuell och reproduktiv hälsa, familjeplanering och genom att förebygga och hantera könsbaserat våld. Programmet syftar till att stärka den institutionella kapaciteten hos hälsovårdsministerier och det civila samhället inom prioriterade stater i Sudan. UNFPAs landprogram omfattar både utvecklingsinsatser och humanitärt stöd. Humanitära behov i denna kontext är ofta långvariga och kräver ett flexibelt tillvägagångssätt som stödjer både utvecklingsinsatser och humanitärt arbete.

tag.narrative: 3.7 - By 2030, ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health-care services, including for family planning, information and education, and the integration of reproductive health into national strategies and programmes.

3.7 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att alla har tillgång till sexuell och reproduktiv hälsovård, inklusive familjeplanering, information och utbildning, och att reproduktiv hälsa integreras i nationella strategier och program.
5.1 - Avskaffa alla former av diskriminering av alla kvinnor och flickor överallt
5.1 - End all forms of discrimination against all women and girls everywhere.
5.3 - Avskaffa alla skadliga sedvänjor, såsom barnäktenskap, tidiga äktenskap och tvångsäktenskap samt kvinnlig könsstympning.
5.3 - Eliminate all harmful practices, such as child, early and forced marriage and female genital mutilation.

Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: In April 2019, UNFPA submitted its annual report to Sida covering activities implemented during 2018. In terms of key accomplishments, the following are noted: • Midwifery: Sudan Midwifery Gap Analysis has been completed, and the midwifery strategic plan has been endorsed. Also, the educational curriculum of the new midwifery diploma has been finalized. They are important prerequisites for conducting midwifery training in 2019. • Emergency Obstetric Care: The EmONC needs assessment has been completed. The EmONC network and geographic information system (GIS) mapping of five pilot states were carried out to identify the facilities that should provide standard comprehensive and basic EmONC services in 2019. These prioritization related efforts are required to guide programming interventions and reach the most-in-need populations. • Family Planning: Sudan Family Planning National Strategy (2019-2023) was developed. This has provided a strategic direction to guide the family planning interventions. Coupled with support provided for family planning supply management and training of health care providers, there is an increasing trend in the number of current users of family planning services. • Gender based violence: Law reform banning female genital mutilation and amendment of articles in the national criminal law is ongoing; this is still work in progress and it is pending parliament endorsement. The map of clinical management of rape (CMR) services has been updated twice (latest update was in September 2018). The mapping assessed the availability and quality of services provided and informed the 2019 planning.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

title.narrative: Stöd till MR-försvarare i Honduras och El Salvador
Support to Human Rights Defenders in Honduras and El Salvador

description.narrative: Strengthen respect for and protection of land and natural resource rights, as well as land and resource rights activists, in Honduras and women’s sexual and reproductive health rights in El Salvador. By the end of the three-year of the initiative, the Fund will achieve the following results: 1) A demonstrated increased capacity among Honduran human rights organizations to defend and promote land and resource rights, as well as to protect human rights defenders working to promote land and natural resource rights; and, 2) A demonstrated increased capacity among El Salvadoran human rights organizations to defend and promote women’s rights, specifically women’s sexual and reproductive health rights. 3) Providing short term support to the independent media in El Salvador, to cover the human rigths situation in the context of the COVID 19 Pandemia. The Fund will accomplish these outcomes through implementing a number of activities in both countries.

Projektförslaget lämnades in av Fonden för globala mänskliga rättigheter och syftar till att stärka respekten för och skyddet av människorättsförsvarare genom att upprätthålla och stärka kapaciteten hos lokala människorättsorganisationer i El Salvador och Honduras.
Fonden för globala mänskliga rättigheter är en ideell organisation som skapades 2002 och är baserad i Washington DC. Fonden har ett latinamerikanskt regionalt program som tillhandahåller vidareförmedling av finansiella medel och teknisk assistans till 56 frontlinjeorganisationer i Mexiko, Guatemala och Honduras. Detta projekt har utformats i nära samråd med lokala intressenter i El Salvador och Honduras.
Fonden kommer att utveckla strategiska portföljer av partnerorganisationer i varje land (5 partners i El Salvador och 8 partners i Honduras). Varje organisation kommer att få ett års operativt stödbidrag, i belopp som sträcker sig från $ 10.000 till $ 35.000.
I El Salvador kommer projektet att stödja organisationer som arbetar med kvinnors rättigheter, med fokus på sexuell och reproduktiv hälsa. I Honduras kommer projektet att stödja organisationer som arbetar med mark- och naturresursrättigheter.
Ambassaden bedömer att det finns ett mervärde att stödja fonden, eftersom den redan arbetar med ett brett utbud av Honduranska organisationer, istället för att stödja enskilt var och en av dem. Fonden identifierade möjliga partners i El Salvador i ett besök som genomfördes i juni 2017.
The proposal was submitted by the Fund for Global Human Rights and it is aimed to strengthen respect for and protection for Human Rights defenders by sustaining and strengthening the capacity of local human rights organisations in El Salvador and Honduras.
The Fund for Global Human Rights is a non-profit organisation based on Washington DC, created in 2002. The Fund has a Latinamerican regional programme which it is providing grant-making and technical assistance to 56 frontline organisations in Mexico, Guatemala, and Honduras. This project has been conceived of in close consultation with local stakeholders in El Salvador and Honduras. The Fund will develop strategic portfolios of grantees in each country (5 grantees in El Salvador and 8 grantees in Honduras). Each organisation will receive one-year operational support grants, in amounts ranging from $10,000 to $35,000.
In El Salvador the Project will support organisations working on women’s rights, with a focus on sexual and reproductive health rights. In Honduras, the Project will support organisations working on land and natural resources rights.
The Embassy assess that there is an added value in supporting the Fund as this organisation it is already working with a broad range of Honduran organisations, instead of supporting individually each one of them. In El Salvador, the Fund already identified possible partners in El Salvador in a visit conducted in June 2017.

The proposal was submitted by the Fund for Global Human Rights and it is aimed to strengthen respect for and protection for Human Rights defenders by sustaining and strengthening the capacity of local human rights organisations in El Salvador and Honduras. Each organisation will receive one-year operational support grants, in amounts ranging from $10,000 to $35,000.

The COP Is made on the base of the travel reports for the field visits to Honduras and El Salvador conducted during last year, and the annual reports submitted by the partner. With the Swedish support, the partner has maintained the strategic portfolio of grantees in each country (eight grantees addressing land and resource rights in Honduras and five grantees addressing sexual and reproductive health rights in El Salvador) working in diverse, yet complementary ways. Each of these organizations have received one-year operational support grants.

strategy.title: Human rights, democracy and the rule of law 2018-2022
strategy.titleSV: Mänskliga rättigheter, demokrati och rättsstatens principer 2018-2022

description.narrative: Overall objective: The proposed intervention aims to improve the state of Ethiopian cities and thereby the urban livelihood by supporting the Government of Ethiopia in implementing the urban component of GTP II in alignment with the SDG 11 and the New Urban Agenda, as part of the UN-Habitat Country Programme for Ethiopia 2016-2020. Moreover, the project specifically assist the selected cities of Ethiopia (Addis Ababa, Adama, Dire Dawa, Hawassa and Mekele) and some regions (Amhara, SNNP and Tigray) in being better planned, more economically productive and sustainable, socially inclusive and environmentally resilient, taking maximum advantage of the on-going development of industrial parks. At the end the intervention the following major results will be achieved; Result 1: City leadership skills are reinforced to enable mayors and city managers to better face the daily challenges of rapid urbanization in their respective cities and towns Result 2: Cities concerned by the development of industrial parks such as Addis Ababa, Hawassa and Mekele, and the SNNP regional state, are able to proactively manage the urban development effects of these parks by enhancing integrated urban/metropolitan planning. Result 3: Municipal staff, communities and local stakeholders of Addis Ababa, Adama and Dire Dawa better understand human-induced and environmental risks and have identified priority actions for building urban resilience. Result 4: Coordination among urban agenda implementing partners in Ethiopia is enhanced. In general, the objective is clearly stated and found to be realistic in addressing urban challenges in the face of expansion of the industrial parks .

Omprogrammerade medel för att bekämpa covid-19 Support to the Implementation of the UN-Habitat Country Programme for Ethiopia: Stöd till genomförandet av FN-habitatprogrammet för Etiopien kommer att sträva efter att förbättra de etiopiska städernas stad och därmed städernas försörjning genom att stödja Etiopiens regering för att genomföra stadsdelen i GTP II i linje med SDG 11 och den nya Urban Agenda, som en del av FN-habitatprogrammet för Etiopien 2016-2020. Specifikt kommer projektet att fokusera på utvalda städer i Etiopien (Addis Abeba, Adama, Dire Dawa, Hawassa och Mekele) och vissa regioner (Amhara, SNNP och Tigray) att vara bättre planerande, med effektiv avfallshanteringsamt mer ekonomiskt produtiva och hållbara, social inkluderade och miljöhärdiga, samt maximalt utnyttja den pågående utvecklingen av industriparker. Ett kompletterande stöd är det globala stödet via SKL ( Sveriges kommuner och landsting) till urban planering,

Reprogrammed funds to address COVID-19 Support to the Implementation of the UN-Habitat Country Programme for Ethiopia will strive to improve the state of Ethiopian cities and thereby the urban livelihood by supporting the Government of Ethiopia in implementing the urban component of GTP II in alignment with the SDG 11 and the New Urban Agenda, as part of the UN-Habitat Country Programme for Ethiopia 2016-2020. Specifically the project will focus on selected cities of Ethiopia (Addis Ababa, Adama, Dire Dawa, Hawassa and Mekele) and some regions (Amhara, SNNP and Tigray) in being better planned, more economically productive and sustainable, socially inclusive and environmentally resilient, taking maximum advantage of the on-going development of industrial parks.

11.a - Support positive economic, social and environmental links between urban, peri-urban and rural areas by strengthening national and regional development planning.

9.2 - Promote inclusive and sustainable industrialization and, by 2030, significantly raise industry’s share of employment and gross domestic product, in line with national circumstances, and double its share in least developed countries.

9.2 - Verka för en inkluderande och hållbar industrialisering. Till 2030 avsevärt öka industrins andel av sysselsättning och BNP, i enlighet med nationella förhållanden, och fördubbla denna andel i de minst utvecklade länderna.

description.narrative:
Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Globalt finns det ca 370 miljoner ursprungsfolk. I Asien lever 260 miljoner urbefolkningar. Två tusen olika civilisationer och språk finns i regionen, vilket gör Asien till den etniskt mest varierande kontinenten i världen. De är mestadels bosatta i avlägsna och oåtkomliga områden och är nära kopplade till mark, naturresurser och lokal försörjning. Ursprungsfolk har under århundraden diskriminerats, utnyttjats och förtryckts av de dominerande grupperna som kontrollerar staten. Diskriminering förekommer i olika former, såsom att undanhålla medborgarskap, förflyttning , utnyttjande av traditionell kunskap, undanhållande av tillgång till juridiskt skydd och rättshjälp, brist på tillgång till välfärd och stöd från civila samhället. Den snabba ekonomiska utvecklingen i Asien har ökat befolkningens levnadsstandard och lyft många ur fattigdom. Sådana framsteg har dock uppnåtts på ursprungsbefolkningens bekostnad eftersom de förblir den mest marginaliserade och utsatta gruppen i samhället och har högre fattigdom än det nationella genomsnittet.
Internationellt finns det rättsliga ramar eller instrument som erkänner ursprungsfolks rättigheter och behovet av att skydda deras rättigheter. FN: s deklaration om ursprungsfolks rättigheter (UNDRIP), antagen 2007, anges en universell ram för minimistandarder för ursprungsbefolkningars överlevnad, värdighet och välbefinnande, som utarbetar befintliga mänskliga rättighetsstandarder och grundläggande friheter som gäller urfolks specifika situation. ILO-konventionen 169 ”När det gäller ursprungsbefolkningar och stamfolk i oberoende länder” belyser ursprungsbefolkningarnas rätt till land, territorier, resurser, kollektiva rättigheter till självbestämmande och rätt till fri och informerat samtycke. Icke desto mindre efterföljs inte de rättsliga ramverken då ursprungsbefolkningens rättigheter ofta ignoreras och kränks. I Asien varierar erkännandet av ursprungsbefolkningar och deras rättigheter på landnivå avsevärt beroende på beslutsfattarnas tolkning och bedömning, som ofta är politiskt driven och inte transparent. Under de senaste åren har det skett en tillbakagång vad gäller de mänskliga rättigheterna, vilket bl a omfattar överträdelser av rättsstatens principer, frekventa fall av straffrihet, minskande av demokratiska och medborgligarättigheter godtycklig arrestering av opposition och hot mot människorättsaktivister . Situationen verkar vara svårare för ursprungsbefolkningar med tanke på belag av land/mark fortsätter att öka och det gör även dödsfall bland MR aktivister. Urbefolkningar löper de största riskerna för att bli utsatta för våld och hot, särskilt de miljö och MR-aktivister. Utöver ovanstående utmaningar hindrar de asiatiska viktiga strukturella utvecklingsfrågorna, svaga rättsstats system. otillräcklig social skyddssystem och bristande medvetenhet om ursprungsbefolkningar möjligheterna för ursprungsbefolkningar att konsolidera sin agenda för kollektiva åtgärder och transformativa förändringar. Det föreslagna ingripandet ”Främjande av ursprungsbefolkningarnas rättigheter i Asien för en framtid för fred, rättvisa och jämställdhet, inlämnat av organisationen Asia Indigenous Peoples Pact (AIPP) syftar till att öka erkännandet och skyddet av ursprungsbefolkningens rättigheter i Asien genom genomförandet av dess strategiska plan som har ett övergripande mål att stärka urbefolkningarnas solidaritet, samarbete och kapacitet i Asien för att främja och försvara deras rättigheter, kulturer och identiteter, och deras hållbara resurshanteringssystem och självbestämande. Det föreslagna stödet omfattar te år från januari 2019 till december 2021. Bidraget från Sverige kommer att täcka det underskottet AIPPs strategiska plan där kostnaderna för aktiviteter inte kan täckas av avtale med andra givare.
För att nå det övergripande målet för den strategiska planen planeras aktiviteterna i enlighet med de fem resultatområdena.
Resultatområde 1: Urfolk i Asien har befogenhet att främja, göra anspråk på och försvara lagligt erkännande av deras identiteter och kollektiva och individuella mänskliga rättigheter inklusive rätten till självbestämmande.
Resultatområde 2: Urfolks olika organisationer i Asien stärks genom att bygga bred solidaritet och samarbete mellan ursprungsbefolkningar såväl som med andra sociala rörelser för att uppnå jämlikhet, fred, demokrati och rättvisa;
Resultatområde 3: Skydd av natur resurser främjas och ursprungsbefolkningars hållbara natur resurshantering inklusive deras färdigheter och traditionella kunskaper för livsmedelssäkerhet, försörjning och skydd av biologisk mångfald förbättras genom att ha full kontroll över deras land/mark, territorier och deras resurser;
Resultatområde 4: Fullständigt och effektivt deltagande av kvinnor och ungdomar såväl som utsatta människor, som personer med funktionsnedsättning och äldre etc., och förmågan att främja och skydda deras rättigheter.
Resultatområde 5: AIPP: s styrning, sekretariat och medlemsorganisationer stärks.
Genomförandet av AIPP: s nuvarande strategiska plan integrerar metoderna kapacitetsuppbyggnad, främjande och lobbyverksamhet, stärkande av organisationer och forskning samt kommunikation i alla programaktiviteter. Verksamheten levereras av AIPP 6-programenheter vilka är Human Rights, Campaign and Policy Advocacy Program, Environment Program, Indigenous Women Program, regionalt kapacitetsuppbyggnadsprogram, kommunikationsutvecklingsprogram och organisationsstärkande och stöd till organisationer . Från utvärderingen av AIPP 2016 lyftes problemet med att det finn en klyfta mellan på lands- och subregional nivå i deras organisationsplanering. För att överbrygga klyftan har AIPP antagit en systematisk nedifrån och upp-process i sin verksamhet under den strategiska planen för att genomföra situation bedömningar, temakartläggning, prioritering och planering. Robust kommunikation och samråd med medlemsorganisationerna och nätverken är nyckeln för AIPP att framgångsrikt bedriva konsultationsmetoden nerifrån och upp Det förväntas att sådan praxis kommer att bidra till att upprätta en regelbunden granskningsmekanism och samordning mellan medlemsorganisationer som gör det möjligt för AIPP att övervinna befintliga hinder och svagheter när det gäller att stärka solidaritet och enhet, brist på gemensam agenda och strategisk samstämmighet i deras förespråkande verksamhet på landnivå. Detta kan också bidra till konsolidering och enande av de inhemska samhällena som för närvarande förblir fragmenterade och inte har kunnat bygga upp sina rörelser effektivt.

tag.narrative: 2.3 - By 2030, double the agricultural productivity and incomes of small-scale food producers, in particular women, indigenous peoples, family farmers, pastoralists and fishers, including through secure and equal access to land, other productive resources and inputs, knowledge, financial services, markets and opportunities for value addition and non-farm employment.

2.3 - Till 2030 fördubbla jordbrukets produktivitet och inkomster för småskaliga livsmedelsproducenter, i synnerhet kvinnor, ursprungsfolk, familjejordbrukare, boskapsskötande nomader samt fiskare, inklusive genom säker och lika tillgång till mark, andra produktionsresurser och insatsvaror, kunskap, finansiella tjänster och marknader samt möjligheter till värdeskapande och sysselsättning utanför jordbruket.

4.5 - By 2030, eliminate gender disparities in education and ensure equal access to all levels of education and vocational training for the vulnerable, including persons with disabilities, indigenous peoples and children in vulnerable situations.

4.5 - Senast 2030 avskaffa skillnaderna mellan könen inom utbildningsområdet och säkerställa lika tillgång till utbildning och yrkesutbildning på alla nivåer för utsatta personer, inklusive personer med funktionsnedsättning, ursprungsfolk och barn som lever under utsatta förhållanden.

description.narrative: Omprogrammerade medel för att bekämpa covid-19 Det huvudsakliga målet med projektet är att stärka kvinnors ledarskap och deltagande i det politiska livet. Det kommer att tillämpa FNs Gender Equality in Elected Office-metod för att få fler kvinnor valda på alla nivåer, inom alla beslutsfattande församlingar i Bosnien och Hercegovina. Projektet kommer att sikta på att öka kvinnors engagemang i det offentliga livet och stärka deras position i beslutsfattandet och försäkra att de har en realistisk och likvärdig chans som deras manliga motparter i de kommande allmänna valen (2018), och på längre sikt, de nästkommande lokala valen 2020. För att stärka kvinnors ledarskap och deltagande i det politiska livet kommer tvådelar strategier att användas - vertikalt genom att föreslå strukturella anpassningar för att få mera kvinnor i politiken samt horisontellt genom att nära nästa generations kvinnliga ledare genom skräddarsydda nätverks- och kapacitetsbyggande initiativ. Följande resultat förutses inom projektet: RESULTAT 1: Stärka kvinnors ledarskap RESULTAT 2: Främja politisk deltagande av kvinnor Projektet kommer att använda "ingångspunkter" och programmeringsmöjligheter för att öppna utrymmen för kvinnors ledarskap och stärka deras deltagande i det politiska livet. FNs kommer att ge samma stöd till alla utan några fördelar mot någon.

Reprogrammed funds to address COVID-19 The main objective of the project is to strengthen women’s leadership and participation in political life. Guided by the strict observance of the highest standards of political neutrality, the project will apply the UNs Gender Equality in Elected Office approach to help secure an enabling environment for getting more women elected across board, in all spheres of decision-making in Bosnia and Herzegovina. It will look into enhancing the women’s engagement in public life and their position in the decision-making and ensure they are given a realistic and equal chance as their men counterparts in the forthcoming general elections (2018), and in the longer term, the next local elections in 2020 by advocacy for women’s equal rights and political participation. Strengthening women’s leadership and participation in political life will apply the two-pronged approach- vertically by proposing structural adjustments to accommodate greater numbers of women in politics, as well as horizontally by nourishing the next generation of women leaders in communities through tailored networking and capacity building initiatives. The following outputs are foreseen within this project: OUTPUT 1: Strengthening Women’s Leadership OUTPUT 2: Fostering Political Participation of Women The project will utilise the “entry points”, contextual enablers, and programming opportunities to open up spaces for women’s leadership and strengthening their participation in political life. UN support will be provided equally to all across the political spectrum with no favours towards anyone.

sector.narrative: Women’s rights organisations and movements, and government institutions

tag.narrative: 5.5 - Ensure women’s full and effective participation and equal opportunities for leadership at all levels of decision-making in political, economic and public life.
5.5 - Tillförsäkra kvinnor fullt och faktiskt deltagande och lika möjligheter till ledarskap på alla beslutsnivåer i det politiska, ekonomiska och offentliga livet.

description.narrative: Conclusion on Performance covers period from 1 December 2017-31 May 2019 and is prepared upon receiving and approving the Annual Narrative/Financial reports. Project activities were designed from the very beginning, but due to unexpected challenges as well as the complex political situation in the previous year marked by a highly negative pre-election campaign and post election lack of forming the government(s), project activities focused on positioning of the project and building of adequate infrastructure for further project implementation, resulting in a two-month delay. From the very beginning, due to the complexity of the political situation and the need to avoid possible controversy and backlash against gender, it was necessary to consult with the UNDP’s Department of Political Affairs in New York. Thus, in May 2018 a meeting was held to draw up the Roadmap for Gender Equality in Elective Offices: Six-step Action Plan, providing very useful steps for contextualizing project activities within BiH. One of the instructions from the UNDP’s Department of Political Affairs included moderation during 100 days of electoral campaigning, which resulted in the cancellation of a media campaign. Therefore, continuation of the project also includes regular consultations with relevant UN counterparts in Brussels and New York, which is to include screening of all concept notes on individual or groups of activities, which can be perceived as politically sensitive.The consultation process for composing the ToR for the Baseline Study took much longer than anticipated. The scope of the Study (both in research and analysis) became considerably broader. While developing the ToR, it also became apparent that the Baseline Study was becoming a vital document for the Project. Concrete measures have been taken on improvement of coordination with UN Women in all phases of implementation of the part of the project they are supporting. Furthermore, low performances of the Team leader created significant delays in implementation of the project activities. Upon resignation of the TL in November 2018, the project advertised position and selected a new TL who managed to accelerate implementation of planned project activities. This procedure has also affected timely implementation of activities. However, despite of initial problems, the project has finalised preparatory activities necessary for selection of beneficiary municipalities, in order to ensure the adherence to the principles of political neutrality, geographic, entity, and ethnic coverage. Communication Strategy and Visibility Guidelines, which are developed in-house with external expert support, aim to ensure strengthening of project profile by incorporating the most relevant visibility activities across the project work. A two-day training for 69 journalists expressing their interest has been delivered in December 2018 in Sarajevo. It is anticipated that the trained journalists will become members of the Media Coalition group within the project once it is formed. The Baseline Study has also been developed to cover variety of relevant issues, horizontally and vertically, covering international best practices, legal environment, media analysis, women in decision making in ten municipalities covered by the project and thorough analysis of programmatic and statutory documents of the main political parties in the country. Relevant methodology that was proposed by the research team indicates that this study brings additional relevant knowledge on BiH realities from the gender perspective. Moreover, the project hired consultant in May 2019 to develop framework and structure the Women Forum for Development which will enhance the establishment of the women leaders’ network. Communication strategy and Guidelines were developed and adopted by the Project Board in May 2019.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

The purpose of this contribution is to maintain activities of the dialogue platform for Syrian CSOs and networks to participate in the peace talks for Syria. description.narrative: The main objective of the intervention is to enhance the inclusiveness of the intra-Syrian talks in Geneva. During the period in question such talks have not resumed, therefor no CSSR activites directly aimed att increasing civil society's participation the talks have been possible. The possibility, and even likelyhood of this, was part of Sida's risk assessment when deciding on an extension of the support to CSSR. However, the Civil Society Support Room has engaged in other activities aimed at strenthening the advocacy of Syrian civil Society towards primarily the UN system and wider international community and feeding in their concerns to the talks taking place outside the framework of the UN-system ("Astana-track"). In November 2018 the UN Office of the Special Envoy organized consultations in Geneva with 29 Syrian participants in various capacities who were given the possibility to feed their cinoncerns so the UN Special Envoy prior to his participation in the upcoming talks in Astana. Following this, the OSE in December 2018 held regional talks in Jordan and Lebanon with the aim of broadening the network of Syrian civil society participants as well as to collect views from these on the future of CSSR (especially given the bleek outlook for future intra-Syrian talks within the UN framework).

title.narrative: COVID-19 Grand Challenges Africa at AESA
COVID-19 Grand Challenges Africa at AESA

description.narrative:
Omprogrammerade medel för att bekämpa covid-19 African Academy of Sciences (AAS) har hos Sida ansökt om 98,4 miljoner SEK för att genomföra programmet Grand Challenges (GC) Africa under perioden 2018-07-01 till 2023-06-30.
GC Africa är ett program som har målsättningen att stödja innovationer som ska bidra till att hitta lösningar för Afrikas utmaningar med att nå de Globala målen för hållbar utveckling. Det grundläggande konceptet bakom alla GC program är finansiering av innovativa idéer riktade mot specifika frågeställningar utan krav på preliminära resultat. GC Africa placerar konceptet i ett afrikanskt sammanhang och definierar frågeställningar/utmaningar relevanta i den afrikanska kontexten och programmet riktar sig specifikt mot afrikanska forskare verksamma vid universitet och organisationer baserade på den afrikanska kontinenten.
Programmet GC Africa har sin bas på Alliance for Accelerating Excellence in Science in Africa (AESA), ett programinitiativ grundat av AAS och organisationen New Partnership for Africa’s Development med syftet att tackla Afrikas utmaningar inom hälsa och utveckling. AESA har etablerat och driver olika program för att stödja forskare och forskning i Africa samt utveckla akademisk ledarskap och initiativ till innovationer. Sidas avtalspartner kommer att vara AAS, en ny partnerorganisation för Sida.
Den planerade totala budgeten för GC Africa programmet är ca. 246,5 miljoner SEK (28 miljoner USD) varav ca 86,5 miljoner SEK (9,85 miljoner USD) är finansierade av Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation, Institute Pasteur och South African Medical Research Council. AAS har en pågående satsning att hitta fler givare till programmet, bland annat ska afrikanska regeringar och filantroper förmås att bidra. Av Sidas stöd till GC Africa kommer ca. 65,4 miljoner SEK att vidareförmedlas till forskningsprojekt.

Reprogrammed funds to address COVID-19 The African Academy of Sciences (AAS) has applied to Sida for funding of 98,4 million SEK to contribute to the Grand Challenges (GC) Africa program during the period 2018-07-01 until 2013-06-30.
The GC Africa program aims at supporting the creation of innovations targeting developmental challenges preventing African countries from attaining the Global Goals for Sustainable Development. The basic concept of all GC programs includes grant support to research projects responding to pre-defined challenges not requiring extensive preliminary data. GC Africa has adapted this concept to the African context and established a program open to African researcher based at African universities and institutions and addresses challenges specific to African development needs.
GC Africa is a program of the Alliance for Accelerating Science in Africa (AESA) that is a programmatic platform founded by the AAS and the organization New Partnership for Africa's Development with the aim to address Africa's health and development challenges. AESA has established and drives different programs to support researchers and research projects in Africa and to develop academic leadership and innovations. Sida will enter into agreement with the AAS, a new partner organization for Sida.
The envisaged total budget of the GC Africa program is approximately 246,5 million SEK (28 million USD), out of which 86,5 million SEK (9,85 million USD) have been contributed by the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation, Institute Pasteur and the South African Medical Research Council. The AAS is in the process of attracting additional funders to the program and is approaching African governments and philanthropists. Of Sida’s support to the GC Africa program approximately 65,4 million SEK will be forwarded to research projects.

The overall objective of the intervention is to promote Africa-led scientific innovations to help countries better achieve the Sustainable Development Goals by awarding seed and full grants to the continent’s most impressive solutions.

tag.narrative: 9.5 - Enhance scientific research, upgrade the technological capabilities of industrial sectors in all countries, in particular developing countries, including, by 2030, encouraging innovation and substantially increasing the number of research and development workers per 1 million people and public and private research and development spending.

9.5 - Förbättra forskningen och industrisektorernas tekniska kapacitet i alla länder, i synnerhet utvecklingsländerna, bland annat genom att till 2030 uppmuntra innovation och väsentligt öka det antal personer som arbetar med forskning och utveckling per 1 miljon människor liksom de offentliga och privata utgifterna för forskning och utveckling.

9.b - Stödja inhemsk teknikutveckling, forskning och innovation i utvecklingsländerna, inklusive genom att säkerställa en gynnsam policymiljö för exempelvis industriell diversifiering och förädling av råvaror.

9.b - Support domestic technology development, research and innovation in developing countries, including by ensuring a conducive policy environment for, inter alia, industrial diversification and value addition to commodities.

title.narrative: Beslut om insats Grand Challenges Africa at AESA

description.narrative: For 2019, Grand Challenges (GC) Africa, a programme of the Alliance for Accelerating Science in Africa (AESA) at the African Academy of Science (AAS), overall reported a total of three new calls for research and innovation grants, progression of work in ongoing grants as well as organization of meetings, workshops and research prioritization exercises. GC Africa has adopted a 3-phase approach supporting Africa-led scientific innovations at proof-of-concept (phase I), transition-to-scale (phase II) and scaling stages (phase III). While projects at the proof-of-concept stage can apply for seed capital to make early, real-world assessments of technical, organisational and financial viability by piloting an innovation in a LMIC context, catalytic capital at the transition-to-scale stage will facilitate business model development and support innovations that have demonstrated success at small scale. At the final scaling stage, growth capital will support widerspread replication and adaptation of an innovation across large geographies and populations for transformational impact. In the GC Africa programme, Sida is supporting calls for proof-of-concept (phase I) and transition-to-scale (phase II) funding. In September 2018, the GC Africa programme had announced its first proof-of-concept call in partnership with Sida. The call Innovation for WASH (water, sanitation and hygiene) in urban settings was part of a global GC call initiative in partnership with Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation (BMGF) and UNICEF seeking for technology-based solutions that promote access to essential resources and services, such as clean water and sanitation, and can make a difference in reducing morbidity and mortality to promote healthy, safe, and productive lives. The WASH call was designed to respond to on-the-ground needs of women, children, and families living in challenging urban environments. The call received a good response from African scientists and research institutions with 166 grant proposals submitted to the GC Africa programme. After initial triage in early 2019, 48 proposals were selected for expert review and each proposal was assessed by three independent external reviewers. Finally, seven projects were selected for funding by a decision committee consisting of representatives from all partners involved in the call. Funded projects are based in Botswana, Congo, Ghana, Kenya, South Africa, Uganda and Zimbabwe. A major milestone in 2019 was the announcement of the first round of GC Africa transition-to-scale grants. In this call, GC Africa invited African innovators that had received proof-of-concept grants in previous calls financed by partners in the GC family, including GC Explorations by BMGF, GC Canada, USAID Centre for Development Innovation, GC South Africa and GC Africa, to submit proposals for transition-to-scale support. The call received 106 applications of which 55 went into a review and curation process. Applications were evaluated by an independent panel of scientific and business experts, and applicants invited to refine their innovations, scaling strategies and business plans and to prepare detailed budgets with projections and global access strategies. Nine innovative projects based in Kenya, Nigeria, South Africa and Tanzania were finally selected for grant support by Sida, BMGF, GC Canada and South Africa Medical Research Council (SAMRC). The GC Africa programme has continued its work to build a so-called e-Marketplace for innovators in Africa. The e-Marketplace is thought as a virtual e-based community of practice where innovators, funders, governments, innovation incubators and other partners can have a secluded, safe and confidential space to share ideas, exchange information, support each other and plan for the success of innovations. To realize the idea, the GC Africa innovation Network (GCAiN, http://gcain.africa) was established and an interactive web-app and mobile application developed and recently launched. The app allows innovators and innovation partners to register profiles in the GCAiN and easily connect with each other. Major collaborators and funders of the GC Africa programme include BMGF, GC Canada, Sida, SAMRC, USAID and Wellcome Trust. The AAS is continuing its efforts to broaden the funding base of the programme and has recently partnered with the German Federal Ministry of Education and Research and in 2019 launched a call for proposals focusing on Maternal and Neonatal Health Innovations. Work is ongoing to further engage African governments in innovation efforts and consider the launch of national GC programmes.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

description.narrative: Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Syftet med insatsen är att förbättra tillsynen på området mänskliga rättigheter (MR) i Ukraina, och då särskilt övervakning och dokumentering av våld och övergrepp som sker som konsekvens av konflikten i de östra delarna av landet. Insatsen syftar till att öka medvetenheten kring människorättsbrott bland relevanta ukrainska och internationella aktörer samt stärka deras kapacitet att identifiera och reagera på kränkningar av de mänskliga rättigheterna.

Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 The aim of the intervention is to improve monitoring of human rights in Ukraine, in particular monitoring and documentation of violence and violations taking place as a consequence of the armed conflict in the Eastern parts of the country. The intervention aims at increase awareness of human rights violations among relevant Ukrainian and international actors and strenghten their capacity to identify and react to human rights violations.

The aim of the programme is to improve the observance of human rights in Ukraine, particularly in respect of violations and abuses stemming from the Russian aggression. The programme will aim at raising awareness of human rights violations among Ukrainian stakeholders, the UN system and the broader international community and at developing the capacity of local stakeholders to identify and address human rights violations.
